requirement_sentence: (Same as WGS 385W 3) This course introduces students to decolonial feminist approaches to history. It considers how history making can be used to advance struggles for racial, gender, sexual and decolonial justice in the contemporary United States. Students will have the opportunity to undertake archival research using materials from Emory Special Collections and Archives. Objectives: By the end of the course, learners will be able to Develop a feasible, critical and self-reflexive research question Complete a review of existing academic literature on their research topic of choice Analyze archival materials using decolonial, anti-racist, feminist and queer perspectives Produce a clearly written, well-argued and strongly evidenced research report Graded elements: In class activities Short informal papers (2 pages) Presentation Final Research Report (5-7 pages)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as REES 423W 1) (This course will concentrate on the broad experience of Muslims within various Russian states. Russia has been Europe's largest Muslim minority state since the 16th century and Muslims still make up about 14% of the Russian Federation's population, making them a major contributor to Russian history. Muslims were variously persecuted, wooed, assimilated, tolerated, forcibly converted, protected, "ignored," "modernized," socialized and granted independence and autonomy by various incarnations of the Russian state. Topics such as the conquest of Kazan and the steppe, the establishment of state-controlled Islam, the colonization of the North Caucasus and Central Asia, the shock of war and revolution, forced secularization, the late Soviet rise of a political Islam, and post-Soviet political Islam will all be discussed. Students will be required to make an oral presentation, write a book review of a class book and write a final research paper.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: What is a profession? What is professionalism? Who are professionals? Combining attention to theoretical issues and case studies, drawing on secondary materials and primary sources (including fiction), and leaving room for independent research by students, History 438 seeks to answer these questions in the context of American history from the Revolution to the present. But at a deeper level the course seeks to explore the nature of professional authority and the meaning of expertise as these have evolved in America. The course thus seeks to examine how and why a key form of non-elected power and influence developed in a nation supposedly dedicated to democracy. And it seeks to examine how and why certain individuals known as professionals came to have that power and influence. No examinations. Grading is based on research essay and class participation.

requirement_sentence: Complete topic: Medieval Lives: Love, Loss, Vengeance & Hatred This course is a social history of the Middle Ages. It takes a thematic approach by focusing on the lives of the elite, city dwellers, the peasantry, and religious minorities (Jews and Muslims). Topics covered include miracles and saints, knightly training, travelers and merchant capitalists, university life, marriage, sex workers, medicine and the Black Death, gender identities, fashion and material culture.

requirement_sentence: SPAN 101 or SPAN_OX 101 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. Spanish 102 is the second course in a beginning-level language sequence and is an integrated skills course designed to promote communication with Hispanic communities and to heighten cultural awareness. Students participate in paired, small-group, and whole-class conversation/listening activities that focus on meaningful communication as well as reading and writing. As such, the goals of this course include the following: 1. learning to use Spanish to communicate, primarily in speaking and listening, but also in reading and writing; 2. learning of and about the tools of communication: basic linguistic units (words, idioms, verb forms, sounds) and grammar (rules which permit you to combine the units meaningfully); 3. and studying Hispanic cultures to begin to understand how culture affects language use. Prerequisite: successful completion of Spanish 101 at Emory, at Emory at Oxford, transfer credit for Span 101 from another institution, or permission of the Director of Placement

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 471W 1) How did an ethnic and religious minority in Europe experience the tumultuous years between 1492 and 1800, known as the early modern period? In this research seminar, students will take a deep dive into the history of European Jews, their relationships and interactions with majority societies, and the profound cultural, geopolitical, legal, religious, and scientific transformations that shaped this remarkable era in European and global history. We will therefore also use Jewish history to illuminate the histories of majority Christian societies. Students will explore themes such as expulsions, mass conversions, persecution, the print and scientific revolutions, the development of Jewish legal systems and Jewish engagement with non-Jewish law, conceptions of self and communal identity, messianism, the Reformations and the Thirty Years' War, mercantilism, and Jewish encounters with the Americas. The course compares Ashkenazi and Sephardi histories while rethinking the complex questions of minority belonging and exclusion. Students will strengthen their ability to analyze a variety of historical sources, including those produced by Jews as well as Christian sources that discuss Jewish life and culture. Students will apply their skills to write a 15-20-page research paper.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. (Same as AFS 389 6) Title: Lusophone Narrative - Literature and History in the Portuguese Speaking World How do literary works present historical events? How do they shed light on moments of deep change in society? How do they uphold, unveil or even challenge long settled structures of inequality brought about by Portugal's maritime expansion begun in the 1400s? This course invites students to reflect on the relationship between literature and history by examining fictional narratives and historical documents from the Lusophone world (Portugal, Brazil, Angola, Mozambique). In addition to practicing their advanced Portuguese, students will engage with some of the most foundational and interdisciplinary questions in literary studies, that is the relationship between literary (fictional) discourse and the historical past. Students will acquire familiarity with some of the most important literary genres from the time of Portugal's colonial expansion, and then examine the various legacies of the early modern period in contemporary novels written in Brazil, Angola and Mozambique. Students will also think through the proposed questions by analyzing documents about important events in Portugal's and Brazil's history, namely the Battle of Alcácer Quibir and the biggest maroon kingdom, the Quilombo dos Palmares. Readings from the early modern period (16th century) include Bernardim Ribeiro, Luis de Camões, Fernão Mendes Pinto, and from the modern period (20th and 21st centuries) Ana Maria Gonçalves, José Eduardo Agualusa, Mia Couto, Paulina Chiziane. Readings in Portuguese, course taught in Portuguese.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: In her essay "How Should One Read a Book?" Virginia Woolf suggests that the best way to experience fiction is to drop all preconceived notions of what a novel can be: "do not dictate to your author; try to become him. Be his fellow-worker and his accomplice." In this course we will become the accomplices of one of the most inventive writers of twentieth-century literature. Reading our way through some of Woolf's major novels as well as selected essays, stories, and autobiographical writing, we will think about Woolf as a critic, humorist, feminist, and literary innovator, with special consideration to the way Woolf reinvents representations of character and human consciousness. While we focus on Woolf's illuminations of the interior self, we will also explore the adventurous artistic and philosophical spirit of Bloomsbury and how her work reflects England's transformation in the first half of the twentieth century: world war and its aftermath, changing social and sexual mores, new conceptions of gender roles and women's rights, advances in human psychology, and contemporaneous developments in painting and design. Texts may include some of the following: Woolf, Night and Day, Mrs. Dalloway, To the Lighthouse, Orlando, Between the Acts; The Waves; A Room of One's Own; Forster, Maurice; Bowen, The House in Paris; Mansfield, stories; Watson, Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day. Expectations: lively participation; weekly short Canvas postings; midterm and final essays.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This seminar dwells at the intersection of aesthetics and ethics. We will read a quite varied body of poems which are addressed to paintings, sculptures, and photographs and monuments. We will proceed via close examination of these test cases. Meetings will demand real-time co-exploration and a willingness to risk saying what we see. We will gain fluency in both the mainstream of ekphrastic verse practices and in several approaches that are not widely used. We will follow our passions and instincts as we explore the possibility of art about art and its associated discourses. We will define and develop and disagree about a set of complex claims regarding one or more of the questions raised by ekphrastic verse, which include: --is the poem accurate in a valuable way, and if it is inaccurate, is its divergence from its object coherent or powerfully imagined? --is the poem obstructive? Not unhelpful? Insightful? Necessary? for what, and for whom? --is the poem a work of art in its own right, and how do we know, and how does that matter? --is the artwork addressed instrumentalized by the poem in any way? En route to a final seminar paper, participants will make two in-class workshop presentations that explore the grounds for their argument(s) as well as the motive(s) deployed in casting of their theses.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Topic: Humans as Drivers of Evolutionary Change This course offers an in-depth exploration of the role humans' and human ancestors, hominins' have played as drivers of evolution in their own lineage and that of other species. Topics discussed include competition between hominin species throughout the 7 million years of hominin evolution, Plio-Pleistocene megafaunal extinctions, hominin-pathogen coevolution, (self-)domestication, evolution in cities and other anthropogenic ecosystems, and the role of humans in the current biodiversity crisis.

Students will have weekly notebook writing assignments/exercises derived from assigned readings and will also compose 5 complete poems. (Same as BIOL 360L 1) (Topic: Neural Data Simulation & Analysis Lab). Students who were on the BIOL 360L/NBB 301 wait list in Fall 2025 AND Spring 2026 graduating senior Biology majors who need to fulfill their upper-level lab requirement have priority for this class. Contact Barbara Shannon at barbara.shannon@emory.edu for permission. Through this course, you will learn basic computational and programming skills and apply them to the simulation and analysis of neural data. Course instructors will provide introductory lessons on basic coding in Python, which will be used throughout the course through collaborative, group-based lab tutorials. The focus of this course will be to use these in-lab tutorials to understand how neuroscience data is structured, analyzed, simulated, and interpreted. The course will be divided into 2 portions: (1) coding, running, and interpreting simulations of neural activity, and (2) understanding the analysis of neural data. The course consists of lectures, group lab tutorials, and individual homework assignments for each module. This course originates in the Biology Department, and it will count as an elective and upper-level laboratory credit for the Biology major. (This course does NOT COUNT as elective credit for the NBB major; the catalog description is incorrect.) Prerequisites: Biology 142/142L and Chemistry 202; pre- or co-requisite: Biology 360/NBB 301).

PLEASE NOTE: Students will need to purchase Blue Books and writing instruments to use in class. Devices will not be permitted. Making People: Empathy and Expertise This is an introductory course on the art of fiction writing. We will focus on elements of craft such as character development, narrative control, dialogue, scene development, setting, structure, openings and endings. We will engage with fiction writing as always about creating human beings with histories, bodies, and social realities; as always about creating a world anew for an audience; and as always a form of communication with an ongoing humanity -- be it dead writers, current beloveds, future anonymous readers or one's own self. Students will come to understand the fiction workshop as a place to face fears, biases and the limitations of the imagination all via practice and hard work. Students will come to see fiction as a place to communicate as writers and critics. Students come to see fiction writing and critical reading as a place to engage bravely and vulnerably with grief, joy and the full range of human emotions between.

Students will strive for excellence and excitement in the regular composition and revision of new poems, as well as an ever-broadening sense of the possibilities of our art. Readings will include full-length poetry collections and essays on craft. title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: What do you know when you know a language? How did you come to learn this information so quickly? How do the world's languages differ? How do linguists study language? This course explores the complex nature of human language and introduces students to the scientific study of human language. As we unpack our knowledge of language, we will explore speech sounds (phonetics), sound systems of language (phonology), word and sentence formation (morphology and syntax), how language expresses meaning (semantics), and how context influences the interpretation of meaning (pragmatics). We will also study language in a broader human context, investigating the role of language in defining human society. Additional topics include historical linguistics, language typology, sociolinguistics, and language acquisition.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course will explore the overlay of language and politics on an island where even what you call a place is it the North of Ireland or Northern Ireland? implies a political stance. You will learn how writers of fiction, plays, and poetry have not only imagined but contributed to cultural and political phenomena from the Irish Revival and the Easter Rising through the Troubles and the peace process. Focusing on Irish literature in English, you will also read some Irish-language literature in translation. Writers are likely to include, among others, Lady Gregory, W. B. Yeats, James Joyce, Seamus Heaney, Nuala Ní Dhomhnaill, and Anna Burns. Expect to read attentively, engage in class discussion, complete a brief in-class reading response or reading quiz each week, practice close reading in essay form, and develop a final project based in the splendid archives and manuscript collections of the Rose Library. Post 1900 Diverse Perspectives II

requirement_sentence: (Same as CPLT 301W 1 and MESAS 370W 1) (Topic - Global Rhymes: Poetry and/as World Literature) (What happens when a sonnet travels across centuries and continents? How does a ghazal resonate in a new language, or an elegy mourn across cultures? From ancient epics to TikTok poetry, what makes poetry travel? And what does it carry with it? While world literature courses often revolve around the novel as the form closely associated with modernity, nationhood, and global circulation, poetry predates the novel, has long and rich histories in many languages and cultures, and continues to shape global consciousness in ways both intimate and political.)

Technical Writing for Data Science - Technical Writing prepares students to analyze complex information and produce clear, ethical, and reader-centered documents across professional contexts. Through hands-on projects and collaborative practice, students will learn to analyze writing contexts, manage the communication life cycle, and adapt style and format to diverse audiences and global contexts. Assignments across multiple genres such as an archival observation report, an interview transcript, and a formal cover letter will help students develop their written, oral, electronic, and visual communication strategies.

requirement_sentence: HLTH 220 and (BIOL 141 or BIOL_OX 141 or CHEM 141 or CHEM_OX 141 or CHEM 151 or CHEM_OX 151) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. Nutrition is at the center of a cultural dialogue about health, though the line between cultural ideology and scientific knowledge is increasingly unclear. In this course, students will learn and use evidence-based nutrition knowledge to critically analyze health-related information, fads, and myths in popular media and translate the scientific evidence to the greater community. (Prerequisite: HLTH 220)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Black British literature has been around roughly as long as African American literature, thanks to the letters and essays of early Black British abolitionists such as Olaudah Equiano and Ignatius Sancho. Unfortunately, it has not enjoyed the same levels of attention and acknowledgement, and even today there are British literary critics unaware that there is in fact a Black British literary tradition that stretches all the way back to the 18th century. It is also as varied, especially in the postwar era as writers from former British colonies in Africa and the Anglophone Caribbean migrated at the government's behest to fill the void left by the loss of English soldiers in World War II. In Britain, there are many ways to be Black, and these novels lay out an array of visions. In this course we'll take a deep dive into the postwar British novel, beginning with Samuel Selvon's iconic The Lonely Londoners, which looks at the experience of the first men who were part of the Windrush generation, and finishing with Bernadine Evaristo's prize-winning epic Girl. Woman. Other., which details some 200 years of Black British women, non-binary folk and trans folk fighting to be recognized for who they are. About halfway through our novels, we'll take a break with some dub poetry and other subversions of the famous stiff upper lip. Diverse Perspectives I & II Theories and Methods

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 258 1, REL 258 1) This is a fascinating time to be - or just learn about - Judaism and Jewishness. We are less than a century out from the genocidal devastation of the Holocaust, the birth of the State of Israel as the first independent Jewish commonwealth in almost two millennia, unprecedented freedom for Jews in many (but not all) parts of the world, and vast migrations by almost every historical Jewish community to a different part of the world than it lived in a century ago. Surely, these are features of the modern Jewish condition we will need to discuss anthropologically. We also live in an age of unprecedented technology and shifts in worldview. Can a genetic profile "prove" Jewishness? In what special ways are some women using assisted reproductive technology or "reproductive tourism" to fulfill Jewish kinship or social and religious expectations? Some of the most interesting anthropological research on Jewish communities today centers on these issues. This class takes place at a moment of increasing political polarization, including confrontations with legacies of (and contested definitions of) race, gender, and antisemitism. Do the new discussions of race and gender, as well as the politics of "diversity, equity and inclusion" make it harder or easier to identify and respond to key elements of the modern Jewish condition, individually or collectively? Has it grown easier or harder to answer the old question whether "Jewishness" is primarily a religious, ethnic, racial or national designation [spoiler: these are not the only options]? Does it matter? To whom? What is actually at stake in these conversations? Finally, we may be at something of a crossroads for the history of anthropology as a research discipline. Along with reading about the sheer diversity of ways of being, thinking, or living Jewishly, we will acknowledge the fraught Jewish history of the anthropological discipline, and ask some critical questions about its future. Is anthropology today capable, given the tools at its disposal, of rendering an adequate account of modern Jewish life? Why, for the most part, has it failed to do so (ok, that's another spoiler alert)? How has the modern Jewish condition impacted the anthropological project from its beginnings, and how might clearer thinking about Jews, Jewishness and Judaism contribute to new forms of anthropological thought? How can we read current ethnographies of Jews and Judaism critically to better understand what they tell us about the Jewish world, how they do it, and what they can learn to do better?

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ANT 440 1 and BIOL 442 1) (Mankind has long recognized that plants are extremely useful as a source of medicine. Medical traditions based on botanical drug sources can be found in all human cultures and date back to prehistory. In this course, both ancient and modern day botanical traditions across many cultures will be discussed as they pertain to medicine. The pathways through which natural drugs are made by plants and how they affect humans will be the focus of this class. Some examples include botanical drugs for infectious disease, cancer, cardiovascular health, dental health, central nervous system function, and much more. By the end of this course, you will have a solid understanding of the major botanical drugs, including their sources, applications, and cultural relevance.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Nineteenth-century American novels are full of fakes: forged documents, phony testimonials, hucksters, impersonators, con-men, and plenty of people who assume false identities to survive. Over the course of the century, the American public became increasingly concerned with the knowability of biological categories we now understand as identities such as race, gender, sexuality, and disability. In what Ellen Samuels has called fantasies of identification, nineteenth-century novels consider the place of truth and authenticity in a nation where nothing was as it seemed. In this class, we will examine the development of the novel in nineteenth century America with a particular focus on identity formation and falsification. Through the work of writers such as Charles Brockden Brown, Catherine Maria Sedgwick, Julia Ward Howe, Hannah Crafts, Herman Melville, Pauline Hopkins, and Henry James, students will become familiar with the movements and traditions of American literature, including early American work, the historical romance, novels of enslavement, the gothic, and naturalism. Course assignments will include weekly preparatory writing, group discussion leadership, and a midterm and final exam. 1700-1900 Diverse Perspectives I & II

At the same time, they have often become the source of discord, as different groups disagreed over what and who should be remembered as heroic and exemplary. requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 270 1, HIST 296 1, and LACS 270 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Tradition-Christianity, Region.) (Throughout history, crimes have tested and measured the social and cultural values that hold human beings together. In a society such as New Spain (Mexico) articulated around the defense and propagation of Catholic religion, religious crimes constituted a threatening subversion of the colonial discourse that justified the Spanish presence in Mexico, and a contradictory expression of the social tensions lived in the Spanish colony. This course will look at colonial society through the lens of crime by analyzing some of the main transgressions prosecuted by the Mexican Inquisition between 1520 and 1820, and the specific historical circumstances in which the trials took place. Our goal will be not only to analyze the reasons for inquisitorial repression, but also to disentangle the tensions lived in the social fabric of the colony in light of the classic divides of race, class, and gender.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: It is an understatement to say that generative AI has transformed the way that writing, art, and discourse are practiced and conceived in the world today. In this so-called era of artificial intelligence, key literary problems around creativity, humanity, and agency resonate in new and powerful ways. At the same time, AI has rapidly become a site to coalesce collective fears around increasing economic inequality, racist and sexist representations, embodiment, and environmental decay. The field of Critical AI studies examines these concerns, critiques big tech and AI development, and offers reparative alternatives for being in the age of AI. In this course, we will read literary fiction to contextualize current debates in the field of Critical AI: from data collection and surveillance to capitalism and machine bias. The semester will culminate by reading literature by writers experimenting with generative AI. Together, we will contextualize our current moment with literature and explore ongoing questions around the ethics of AI development and use. What literary methods and tools can the field of Critical AI borrow as analytic frameworks? And what does literature offer in the face of technology and automation? Post 1900

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course covers the evolution of the hominin lineage - humans and fossil apes more closely related to us than to chimpanzees and bonobos. Hominin evolution is documented by an exceptionally rich - and ever-expanding! - fossil record, which provides evidence of remarkably diverse adaptive strategies within our lineage, as well as the evolutionary drivers of this diversity. The course is structured chronologically: we begin with the earliest putative hominins dated to 7-4 million years ago, and then examine diversity within the well-known Australopithecus genus and the enigmatic Kenyanthropus clade. Next, we consider the alternative responses to climate change evidenced by two sister groups - Homo and Paranthropus - and then continue with an in-depth exploration of the drivers of evolution and dispersals within the genus Homo. At the end of the course, students will have a strong understanding of the hominin fossil record and the state-of-the-art methods and frameworks used to understand it, but also be able to critically engage with important open questions about the evolution of our lineage. No textbook.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course offers a rigorous introduction to social choice theory, the formal study of how individual preferences, values, and judgments can be aggregated into collective decisions. The course begins with the necessary logical and mathematical foundations, covering propositional and predicate logic, basic set theory, and binary relations. We then develop the theory of individual choice and rationality, examining orderings, preference relations, maximality, acyclicity, and rational choice functions, along with Sen's conditions ( and ß) and Houthakker's Weak Axiom of Revealed Preference. Building on this foundation, the course turns to social aggregation mechanisms, including classical voting rules, their axiomatic characterizations (e.g., May's Theorem, Black's Theorem), and the challenges posed by Arrow's axioms and his celebrated impossibility theorem. We also study issues of manipulation, strategy-proofness, and the Gibbard-Satterthwaite theorem. The course concludes with broader normative debates, including Sen's impossibility of a Paretian liberal and Gibbard's theory of alienable rights. Throughout, students will engage both with formal proofs and with the philosophical and institutional implications of the results, making the course suitable for students in political science, philosophy, and economics who are interested in the logic and limits of collective decision-making. Prerequisites: Some prior exposure to formal methods (logic, mathematics, or microeconomic theory) is recommended.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course examines the human skeleton as both a living biological system and the product of our evolutionary history. We will investigate skeletal form and function from head to toe through the combined perspectives of comparative anatomy, growth and development, and evolutionary biology. By comparing humans to our primate cousins, the course highlights how the skeleton is reflects specializations for locomotion, diet, and aspects of life history. On the way we will explore topics like how skeletons can adapt to environmental conditions during development, and why some parts of the body can more easily evolve than others. We will trace how evolutionary tinkering with the ancestral primate body plan gave rise to the human form, where our bodies still bear signs of this shared ancestry, and how these evolutionary legacies can underlie modern health challenges. The course balances lectures with laboratory sessions. In the lab, you will gain hands-on experience with human and non-human primate skeletal material, learning to identify anatomical features, interpret functional differences, and connect them to evolutionary processes. By the end of the course, you will have developed a deep understanding of human skeletal biology and its broader links to evolution, behavior, and health.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course will examine the history of the Chinese presence in the United States, especially as it has been expressed in literature and popular culture. Our historical range will include the importance of Chinese trade and Chinese goods in the American Revolutionary War, the Gold Rush and the construction of the transcontinental railway, the exclusion era, and the resurgence of Chinese immigration in the late twentieth century and continuing to the present day. We will study works of social and cultural history, memoirs, fiction, poetry, and film by and about Chinese Americans. The emphasis will be on understanding the connection between the historical context of these works and the particular concerns and shape of those works.

requirement_sentence: Dystopian novels have been so prominent in recent fiction that critics have described our time as a golden age for the genre. The result has been that, as one writer puts it, "there's a book for every type of modern dread." Particularly notable in this current dystopic outpouring has been the influence of women writers. This course juxtaposes the most famous dystopia written in English, George Orwell's 1984, with novels by contemporary women writers (Ling Ma, Octavia Butler, Margaret Atwood, and one TBA) to explore how their works are reshaping the genre. The imaginative societies envisioned by these writers pose crucial questions about where the real dangers lie for our future and our present through their groundbreaking dystopic novels. Requirements are active & informed class participation; occasional response paragraphs; 2 short papers, one potentially optional. Post 1900 Diverse Perspectives II Prose

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Thinking about writing an honors thesis? Whether you are a yes or a maybe, you probably aren't sure how to get started, and like many students you may be feeling intimidated or uncertain about identifying a topic, doing independent research, or getting the help you need. Seniors consistently say writing a thesis was the most rewarding experience of their undergraduate education, yet many well-qualified students miss the opportunity or give up because they started too late. If you are an honors-curious junior or sophomore in the humanities or qualitative social sciences, this class is for you! Taught in a workshop/seminar format that will create a supportive, interdisciplinary intellectual community, this class is designed to facilitate your individual exploration process and help you get a head start on your project in conversation with peers and mentors. As you identify and begin to develop your research project, you will formulate or refine your topic and methods, explore what our library has to offer, enhance your oral communication skills, and work with faculty mentors to develop a plan for success. Starting early will also enable you to identify and apply for opportunities (such as funds for travel to archives and senior research seminars) that will enhance your project and provide invaluable experience. This workshop will support you in getting started on your honors thesis and help you put together the pieces that will lead to a successful outcome in your senior year.

Through music, videos, and readings of authentic materials, students are also introduced to many aspects of Lusophone culture. Class meets four times per week and is conducted in Portuguese in order to maximize exposure to the language. title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same LING 347 1, AAS 347 1) African American Language (AAL) is by far the most researched, the most publicly recognized, and most controversial language variety in the United States. AAL has long been a central object of study in North American sociolinguistics, where researchers have investigated its structure, its origins, and its current trajectories of change relative to Mainstream American English, and have simultaneously sought to combat misunderstandings about AAL (and all language differences) held by the public and the press. This course will be broken into four major sections: 1) Present-Day Features of AAL, with a focus on its vocabulary (lexicon), pronunciation features (phonetics and phonology) and grammar (morphology and syntax); 2) The History of AAL and its ongoing trajectory of change, focusing on earlier examples of AAL, its possible origins and whether or not AAL is diverging from Mainstream American English (MAE) and other varieties of English; 3) AAL as a Living Art will discuss AAL as it is employed as an expression of art by writers, musicians, as well as its use in African American speech events, and avenues for outreach; 4) AAL, Education and Society will examine issues related to AAL and education, the justice system, linguistic profiling and discrimination in other areas of society such as housing and employment.

requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 378 1) (This course examines 2 of the most significant African American cultural movements of the 20th century - the New Negro Renaissance (aka the Harlem Renaissance, c. 1912-1932) and the Black Arts Movement (c. 1965-1979). While placing a primary emphasis on literary arts and authors, we will approach both movements as complex interdisciplinary, multi-generic phenomena concerned with Black freedom struggles. As we "map" the histories of these two major movements, we will consider the ways artists and critics alike have constructed these movements, the relationships of these movements to each other and to Black Studies, and the processes and politics that shape notions of literary history, race, gender, sexuality, and culture in American society.)

requirement_sentence: Portuguese 212 aims to further develop communication skills in Portuguese and explore issues related to power and social struggle in the contemporary Portuguese speaking world. We will discuss and analyze fictional works, films, music and primary sources, in order to understand and learn how Portuguese speakers have faced challenges such as dictatorships, immigration and emigration, as well as racial, gender and social inequality issues that have been historically present in Lusophone countries. Students will learn to recognize aesthetic constructs, the representation of genre differences and similarities, ideological trends, and historical contexts, as well as formulate responses in Portuguese to the various themes addressed in the different texts and films, both orally and in writing. Students will be required to compose creative and analytical responses to the course materials and will revise their compositions with feedback from their peers and instructor. We will review Portuguese grammar with an emphasis on verbs and their complements (prepositions), pronouns and the nuances of the Portuguese language structure. All classes will be conducted in Portuguese. PREREQUISITES: Port 201 or equivalent (including courses taken during a study abroad program).

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: ECON 220 or ECON_OX 220 or HLTH 207 or MATH_OX 117Q or QTM 100 or QTM_OX 100 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. This course introduces students to key concepts in health research. It uses didactic and applied training to develop competency in research methods, both quantitative and qualitative. The course introduces the basic steps, methods and strategies of the research process; problem identification, hypothesis development, literature review, research design and methodology, data management, data analysis, and scientific communication. Its aim is to help students design and develop a thoughtful, persuasive, and potentially fundable scientific research proposal that addresses a health concern. Students begin with a broad health topic that they would like to investigate and learn how to narrow it down into a specific and feasible research question; then they learn how to design a methodology to address the question. In addition to comprehending and developing the elements of a research project, students also learn the principles of ethical conduct of research, essentials of scientific writing, as well as presentation skills. Students also learn how to conduct a literature review, how to evaluate the literature, and how to use a reference management software. (Prerequisites can be any one of the following: HLTH 207, OR QTM100, OR MATH_OX 117Q, OR ECON 220 - If any issues enrolling with one of these prerequisites, please contact Savvy.Mcleod@emory.edu)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: MUS 270: Bach and His World Stephen Crist This course explores the life, music, and influence of Johann Sebastian Bach (1685 - 1750), one of the most significant figures in the history of European classical music. We will examine and discuss representative musical compositions of all genres and from all chronological periods of his career, selected documents concerning Bach's biography and aesthetic views, and some of the most recent and important writings in Bach research. We will also consider the social, political, and religious contexts within which Bach worked. Activities include weekly discussion posts, several short reaction/summary papers, and a final course synthesis. In addition, each student will do a project that They'll present in class and submit as a paper. The course is open to all students, both musicians and non-musicians.

We will begin with a review of the evidence on climate change and variability and explore a number of topics related to climate change of interest to the anthropological and global health community, such as: Disparate Impacts: The Global North vs the Global South; Food security: Climate change impacts on food quality and quantity; Climate change and biodiversity loss; Environmental Justice as a policy frame; Arctic and Circumpolar health issues; Indigenous perceptions of climate change; Impacts on oceans; Climate Refugees: Migration and population displacement. (Prerequisite: HLTH 250)

(Topic: People and Their Gods) (This course provides a survey introduction to the study of the distinctive and interrelated cultures of the ancient Mediterranean world, from the Bronze Age until the Christianization of the Roman Empire (ca. 3300 BCE to ca. 400 CE). Under the subtitle, "People and Their Gods," the course gives special attention to cultural phenomena identified with the category of "religion." Drawing on a range of evidence, both material and literary, we will explore how ancient Mediterranean people understood and interpreted stories about gods and other powerful beings ("myths"); polytheism and monotheism; veneration of images ("idolatry"); tradition and innovation in religious beliefs and practices; the sexualities of gods and human beings; the significance of sacrifice (including human sacrifice); how Jews and Christians viewed so-called "pagans" and how "pagans" viewed Jews and Christians; the ancient Mediterranean roots and sources of present-day religious traditions.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Louise Erdrich, a citizen of the Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa, is among the most prolific and highly acclaimed authors of our time. This course focuses on her fiction, especially her novels Tracks, The Round House, and The Night Watchman, along with her children's novel The Birchbark House. We will also engage some of Erdrich's poetry and non-fiction prose, interviews with her, and scholarship about her work. Erdrich depicts Indigenous people's experiences with boarding schools, sexual violence, land theft, anti-colonial resistance, Indigenous feminisms, and Anishinaabe teachings. We will discuss these topics and consider how Erdrich's craft contributes to her portrayal. We will also explore the impact of Erdrich's work for law, politics, pop culture, and education.

requirement_sentence: Understanding, providing, and advocating for care is paramount in today's complex and interconnected world. This course delves into the multi-faceted nature of care, examining it through various lenses and contexts. Whether you aspire to work in healthcare, social services, or education or want to enhance your understanding of human relationships and well-being, this course equips you with the knowledge and skills to become a more compassionate and effective caregiver. This course will give students a comprehensive understanding of the concepts of care and their practical applications. Students will be better prepared to engage in compassionate caregiving as healthcare professionals, educators, community advocates, or individuals dedicated to creating a more caring and empathetic world. Join us in exploring the profound art and science of care today. Special Note: HLTH 385 courses count differently within the majors/minors; they are not all equivalent. title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Black artists often turn to speculative and fantastic genres to illustrate the strange qualities of Black life informed by racism and oppression but also resilience and strength in the face of these structural challenges. In this course, we will read, watch and play through Black speculative fiction narratives to better understand how Black artists have imagined alternatives to the status quo and what these alternative worlds signify about our own. The material for this class will be composed of novels, short stories, films, and video games. As we engage with the works of Black artists, this course will encourage us to compare forms of media and analyze the specific a¿ordances of each one. By taking this course, students can expect to gain an understanding of Black speculative fiction as a genre with a unique history that transcends individual media, reflect on Black speculative fiction as a microcosm of American culture at large, and analyze the various intersections of race, gender and sexuality which inform many of the narratives we will encounter. In response to the multi-modal nature of our course, students can expect to produce work in multiple genres and modes, including written essays, visual presentations, and interactive experiences. Diverse Perspectives I Theories and Methods

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: In this course, we will pursue a historically grounded study of Indigenous American fiction, non-fiction, and poetry produced between the mid-nineteenth century and the present. We will read texts written during the periods of history they represent as well as more recent texts depicting the US Dakota war, the Navajo Long Walk, the Wounded Knee massacre, Indian boarding schools, allotment, reorganization, termination/relocation, Red Power movements, the Native American renaissance, and the AIDS epidemic. We will also read recent literary texts that portray current and future work related to cultural/political resurgence, LGBTQ2+ empowerment, language revitalization, and environmental restoration. Throughout the course, we will draw connections between these literary texts/contexts and current issues of concern for Indigenous nations. All students are expected to complete reading and writing assignments as scheduled and participate in discussions and assessments.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course provides a general introduction to the study of Asian American literature and culture through the politics of fantasy and from a global framework. Instead of taking "Asian America" as a given, we will explore its construction by tracing how "Asia" and "America" have been imagined separately and together. Placing these fantasies in relation to histories of immigration, imperialism, militarism, and globalization, we will investigate how Asian American writers and artists engage with and intervene in the imagining of Asian America. Throughout, we will pay special attention to the racial fantasies that adhere to everyday objects, including food, fashion, toys, media, and other forms of popular culture. Texts will range from the classic to the contemporary and encompass fiction, poetry, nonfiction, comics, and other media. Topics to be discussed will include: Orientalism and the yellow peril; the model minority; stereotyping and microaggressions; media representation; racial fetishism; drag and racial performance; interracial romance; refugee politics; intergenerational memory; techno-Orientalism; globalization and soft power; kawaii culture; weebs and fandoms. Post 1900 Diverse Perspectives I & II

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Why do sick people tell stories? Whom or what do illness narratives serve? What do illness narratives help ill people (re)construct? What are the distinctions between healing and curing? What are the individual and collective facets of illness? These are some of the questions we will contemplate in this course alongside others pursuing answers to similar inquiries. We will read a variety of illness and healing narratives in a myriad of forms (novels, poems, plays, short stories, essays) by considering such cultural expressions in relation to the development of an interdisciplinary field of literary criticism and the founding of an accompanying journal (Literature and Medicine, founded in 1982). The stories we read in this class will also help us consider other matters e.g., conceptions of hope, dignity, death, pain, and meaning in the midst of chronic and/or debilitating illness and terminal illness. Diverse Perspectives I & II Theories and Methods

requirement_sentence: (Same as LING 363W 1) Pre-1700 One semester of intensive language study will result in a proficient reading knowledge of the West Saxon dialect (standard Old English) such that we can explore the culture of the Anglo-Saxons and better understand the language we speak today. Selections from heroic and religious poetry and prose will begin with the first known poem in the English language and will also include the Wanderer and Seafarer, the Battle of Maldon, the Dream of the Rood, Ælfric's preface to Genesis, and King Alfred's lament over the faded glory of English learning. Classes consist of prepared translation, short lectures, and discussion. The standard lexicographic and bibliographic tools in Old English will be covered. Some previous foreign language study is desirable but not required; students should be prepared to use a glossary. We will also read Beowulf in translation, as well as selected passages in Old English.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course covers the full range of Geoffrey Chaucer's poetry, including his dream visions, Troilus and Criseyde, and selected Canterbury Tales. Chaucer creates in English the stories and forms found in classical (e.g. Ovid's Metamorphoses and Virgil's Aeneid), vernacular (e.g. those by Dante, Boccaccio, and Guillaume de Lorris) and biblical traditions. Chaucer is at his best when overturning the conventions of epic, romance, fabliau, Breton lay, saint's life, and exemplum. We shall explore at least three of the great mysteries of Chaucer's life and work: how such a prolific poet could also be a soldier, diplomat, and court official; how his poetic persona consistently veils and deprecates his genius; and how his relationships with people from different social classes and sexes finds poetic expression. A class project will involve work with manuscript facsimiles in Emory's Rose Library.

Students will comprehensively understand the real estate lifecycle, key players, and emerging technologies transforming traditional practices. The course will examine pain points, inefficiencies, and opportunities for innovation in the real estate sector while also analyzing the challenges faced by new technologies in gaining widespread adoption. Engagement with executives from PropTech startups and established real estate firms will provide real-world insights into the practical applications and challenges of implementing innovative solutions.

requirement_sentence: This course will introduce students to major works of British literature (including poetry, drama, and prose) dating roughly from the death of Elizabeth I in 1603 to the restoration of the monarchy in 1660. We will adopt a broadly historicist approach, devoting special attention to the relation between the period's literature and the politics of the English Civil War (1642-1651). This approach, however, will not be at the expense of attention to the formal and thematic qualities of individual works. The course will be divided into six units: 1) Metaphysical and Cavalier Poetry, 2) Jacobean Drama, 3) Gender Relations in the Seventeenth Century, 4) Empiricism and Experience, 5) The Literature of the Civil War, and 6) Milton's Paradise Lost. title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course examines the intriguing relationships between religion, spirituality, and jazz. It considers the common roots of the spirituals, blues, and jazz, and surveys the historical, cultural, social, and denominational factors that have helped to shape our perspective on the spiritual capacity of jazz. Any exploration of this type must include an interrogation of the intersection of race, racism, and ethnicity. Notions of the sacred/secular as well as the origins of the stigmas associated with jazz as the devil's music will be examined in detail. This course will focus on the sacred works, biographies, and implicit theological positions of six jazz masters: Mary Lou Williams, Dave Brubeck, Duke Ellington, John Coltrane, Sun Ra, and Yusef Lateef. Each of these masters elected a distinct and different path in the musical expression of their spirituality. Significant Buddhist (Herbie Hancock) and Baha'i (Dizzy Gillespie) jazz communities will also be considered.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course will offer a survey of some of the most exciting, innovative, and intellectually provocative novels published in eighteenth-century Britain. A touchstone for our discussions will be the philosopher John Locke's reinvention of the human mind, in his 1690 Essay Concerning Human Understanding: "Let us then suppose the mind to be, white paper, void of all characters, without any ideas; how comes it to be furnished?" Locke's answer to this question, "experience," had an enormous impact on the intellectual landscape of the century that followed. On the one hand, Locke's argument that our ideas are derived from the senses suggested that individuals are the products of their own experience, and thus have, in some measure, the power to shape their own lives. On the other hand, the shaping power that Locke attributed to experience conjured up the danger that our minds and our lives are always at the mercy of various external forces: including family and friends, enemies and competitors, as well as an array of social, cultural, and political settings, institutions, and ideologies. More than any other form of literary expression in the eighteenth century, the novel took up the challenge of imagining and embodying, even at times resisting, the power of experience. We will study the novels of Daniel Defoe, Samuel Richardson, and Jane Austen, among others. Written work will include 3 essays, weekly Canvas postings, and a take-home final exam. of exams and essays

requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 190 1) (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) Description: When and why did Jews immigrate to Latin America? What kinds of challenges did they face in their new societies? What about Latinx Jews: how do they fit into the so-called "American story"? This course will introduce students to the history and cultures of Jews in Latin America as well as Latinx Jews in our own country. Issues we will address include acculturation and assimilation; language preservation and acquisition; ethnic and racial identities; the role of religion; family life, among others. Texts will include memoirs, novels and short stories, documentary and fiction films, poetry, journalism, music, cookbooks, and scholarly essays. The seminar will also feature guest speakers. No prior knowledge of Jewish culture or religious traditions is required or assumed. Course readings and discussions are conducted in English. Evaluation: Active participation in seminar discussions; weekly postings on Canvas; 2 short essays (~5 pp.); final project.

requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 221 1) (The media has often depicted Africa as a continent in turmoil, underlining military coups, war, famine, and disease. Yet those portrayals overlook the historical complexities that have led to current events. In this course, we aim to challenge limited narratives of Africa's contemporary realities by delving into the people, events, and processes that have shaped the continent. Given the vast size of Africa, the course will focus on specific themes and cases. These will include the end of the Atlantic slave trade and the transition to "legitimate" commerce; the motivations for and establishment of colonial rule; economic, social, and cultural transformations; African resistance to colonialism and decolonization; and post-colonial political trajectories. Altogether, this course examines the internal and external dynamics of change in Africa.)

requirement_sentence: This section is reserved for students in the BBA program. While most people list happiness as one of their central life goals, people are surprisingly bad at knowing what will make them happy. In this course, we will explore what science can tell us about what actually makes people happy both personally and professionally. We will begin by examining how scientists define and measure happiness and some of the benefits of happiness for individuals and organizations. Next, we will examine the features of our minds that often make us less happy and how to combat them. We will then turn to what science can teach us about how to be happier, less stressed, and more fulfilled in our personal and professional lives. Students will have multiple opportunities to put these practices into action and will be encouraged to develop ways to build them into their current and future lives.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as LING 304 1) Dr. Deborah Tannen, a Distinguished University Professor of Linguistics at Georgetown, was once asked the following question: "Deborah, do you like your hair like that?" 1. Why don't we ask, "Your hair do like you like that?" 2. Does like have the same meaning in both uses? 3. Are the r's in "Deborah" and "hair" pronounced the same? 4. Who asked the question, and does it matter? Is the utterance really even a question? 5. How does our interpretation change if we know more about the tone of the utterance? The answers to these questions and others similar are what we'll explore in Span/ Ling 304, starting with a general history of the field of linguistics and what human communication entails before moving into detailed discussions of the production and organization of the sounds of Spanish (fonética y fonología); the formation, structure, and meanings of words (morfología); the structure and organization of sentences (sintaxis); analyses of meaning of words, sentences and conversations (semántica y pragmática); and examples of linguistic variation. TEXT: Hualde, José Ignacio, et. al. Introducción a la lingüística hispánica (2da edición). New York: Cambridge University Press, 2013. PARTICULARS: Because this is an introductory course to Hispanic linguistics, no previous study of Linguistics is required, but the course is taught in Spanish. Span/ Ling 304 is a core course of the Spanish & Linguistics Joint Major and a foundational course for the Spanish Major and Minor and the Major in Spanish and Portuguese. ***If SPAN 304 is at full capacity, please consider enrolling in LING 304, which will satisfy the same major requirements and the IC requirement.*** EVALUATION is based on active class participation, homework assignments, exams (two midterms and a final) and a project/ presentation due at the end of the semester. PREREQUISITE: SPAN 212, permission of instructor, or an Official Spanish Placement into our Foundational Course level (Span 300-318). For more information on Foundational Courses, please go to www.spanport.emory.edu. Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html

requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 268 1, HIST 268 1, MESAS 268 1) The Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: Political Struggles, Personal Histories gives students an overview of Israeli-Palestinian conflict from the 1880s on through today. It introduces students to early Zionist debates and the late Ottoman context before moving on to discuss violence during the British Mandate period, the rise of the State of Israel, and the reappearance of the Palestinian cause on the world stage after the 1967 war. The course will include sessions that examine previous bouts of armed conflict as well as various attempts at peace, but war and politics will not be the course's only foci; the lived experiences of Palestinians and Israelis will also receive significant attention, from historical times through the present day. These voices include a young Jewish female spy who helped the British defeat the Ottoman Empire; an Islamist rebel whose death inspired the Great Arab Revolt of the 1930s; a Holocaust survivor who fought in the 1948 war before becoming Israel's leading poet; girls whose families fled from Jerusalem and Libya, and grew up amidst poverty and war; a U.S.-trained heart surgeon-turned-PLO militant who was assassinated in his quest for peace, and many others.

Students will participate in mock simulations, conduct in-depth research on the economies and business practices of Spanish-speaking countries, and also develop their own professional portfolios relevant to their own fields. Through a comprehensive exploration of business practices, cultures, and the global economy, students will gain a robust foundation in the vocabulary and communication skills necessary for success in international business and cultural economics. This hands-on approach will provide tangible outcomes, preparing students for real-world professional scenarios. Course topics: International Markets, Real Estate, Business Management, Human Resources, International Cultural Economics & More. Prerequisite: SPAN 212 or an Official Spanish Placement into our Foundational Course level. Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html.

Drawing from methods derived from post-modern dance and improvisation, and utilizing movement material borrowed from butoh, contemporary dance, and the individual movement lineages of participants, we as a class will create a repertory piece that will be performed at the Emory Dance Concert in April. How are these struggles depicted in novels, documentary films, journalism, activist publications, and other forms? Prerequisites: a Foundational Spanish Course or SPAN 217 (Spanish for Health Care).

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course explores the intersection of patriarchy, racism, and violence in 21st-century Latin American film. Students will examine how various family formats are portrayed on film, and to what extent they construe, challenge, and/or otherwise reproduce influential concepts (such as care, work, motherhood, childhood, decency, masculinity, or promiscuity) across gender, racial, and/or class-based lines. In examining these issues, we will look at how People of Color, Women, Children, and members of the LGBTQ+ collective bear the brunt of abuse and generalized violence brought against them due to the sheer fact that they dare to exist. We will also explore the concept of patriarchy paying attention to the many traits that turn masculinity in particular, and cisheteronormativity in general, (as well as subtle forms of white supremacy-ism) into vigilance vectors bent on building "the normal". In analyzing narrative depictions that address the aforementioned forms of inequality, the class will discuss to what extent State-sponsored forms of violence manufacture hegemony, neutralizing and destroying any detectable "deviance" from a desideratum for docile and malleable citizens that remains under constant (de)construction. EVALUATION: Participation in class, written critical responses, an oral presentation, and a final research essay. PREREQUISITE: At least one foundational course (SPAN 300-318W) or permission from the instructor.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ITAL 375W 1) Content: Do you want to know more about the Mafia and the Godfather? This is an offer you can't refuse. Touching on witchcraft, the evil eye, and life in Little Italy, you will learn whether Alfredo Sauce is authentically Italian and what it meant to be an Italian immigrant at the turn of the 20th century. Several millions of Italian immigrants came to the United States to work for the industrial development of the county's economy at the end of the 19th century. This course aims at introducing you to the fascinating study of the Italian American presence in the United States and its impact. Through movies, articles and primary sources we will look at the historical, political, literary and artistic achievements of Italian immigrants in the United States to understand what it means to be an American of Italian descent in the 21st century. This course is taught in English and does not require any knowledge of Italian. It fulfills Continuing Communication and Race & Ethnicity Requirements) Text: Connell, W. J., & Pugliese, S. G. (Eds.). (2017). The Routledge History of Italian Americans. Routledge.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as LACS 490RW 1) In this class we ask: what exactly are "borders," "borderlands," and "border spaces"? How do they function? How can we understand the Mexico-U.S. frontera/border within both historical and contemporary contexts? How does that border inflect other "border spaces" far away from its geography, including spaces in Atlanta? The course looks at how the stories of these borders are shaped and then re-told, in written and visual texts. The course is taught primarily in Spanish while also integrating the multi-lingual nature of border stories. We will partner with the Latin American Association, whose building on Buford Highway can be described as a border space, and we will engage with a visiting artist, Yehimi Cambrón. You will complete a collaborative project that supports the Latin American Association's work and provides a framework for you to actively reflect on the integration of the humanistic inquiry (like this course) in your own future work. PREREQUISITES: At least one Foundational Course (SPAN 300 - 318W), or one 400-level Spanish course, or permission from the instructor.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Why is language structured the way it is? How and why is it limited in what it can express? Answers to questions such as these usually stem from two opposing views. One focuses on language and meaning as products of how the mind works. The other stresses language as a product of social interaction. In this course, we will consider a series of questions to better understand these two views. Topics will include what the sources of linguistic structure might be; whether (or how much of) language is innate in humans; how language reflects categories and helps us form categories; and to what extent language influences thought. The course is only available to graduating seniors who have declared the following majors or minors: Linguistics, Psych/Ling, Span/Ling, or QSS major w/ concentration in Linguistics. Permission number required to enroll, contact: dbolde2@emory.edu. Required Textbook(s): No textbook required; readings will be available on Canvas.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as SPAN 413W 1) This course provides a descriptive and critical overview of the linguistic practices of different Spanish-speaking communities in the United States, as well as a methodology for the study of these practices. Students will learn about the linguistics characteristics of the different Spanish varieties spoken by these communities, including phonetic, morphological, syntactic and lexical aspects. Special attention is given to the relationship between language and society, particularly on topics such as ethnic and cultural identity, multilingualism and language policy. The course also presents a theoretical and practical approach to the ethnographic research method. Students will read and analyze studies carried out by different scholars and will design their own research project on the topic of their preference. Special attention is given to ethical principles, for this reason students will need to complete the web-based Collaborative IRB Training Initiative (CITI) Program in the Protection of Human Subjects in Research. Background on general Linguistics is recommended, such as the one provided in Span/Ling 303, Span/Ling 304 or Ling 201.This course meets the sociocultural requirement of the Linguistics Major and can be used as one of the required 400-level courses for the Joint Major in Spanish & Linguistics or for the Major/Minor in Spanish. TEXTS: - Escobar, Anna María and Kim Potowski. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. - Selection of articles available in Canvas. EVALUATION: Evaluation will be based in class participation, weekly assignments, one exam, one research project and five written practices. PRE-REQUISITES: One foundational course, preferably SPAN/LING 303 or SPAN/LING 304.

requirement_sentence: This course will equip and enable you to contribute to the Emory Voices Project-- a large-scale linguistics project that aims to collect and analyze the speech of Emory undergraduates. We intend to study Emory's linguistic community by interviewing undergraduates at the beginning and end of their time in college. In these interviews, we will target specific linguistic characteristics, inquire about language attitudes, and elicit natural speech. You will learn about the sociolinguistic interview process, develop skills working with linguistic corpora, and study other relevant topics within linguistics to inform your work on the project. This course will also allow students to formulate and address a research question of their choosing. Course is open to students of all years and skill levels. Prior completion of at least one Linguistics course recommended.

(Topic: China and Japan) (This is an introduction to the major religious traditions (Confucianism, Daoism, and Buddhism) in China and Japan. The course will contextualize the religions in the larger frame of popular religious practices. We will also examine the patterns of interactions among these traditions in different historical periods. Our themes will include: the invisible world of gods and spirits, worldly benefits, religion and state, and the lives of shrines, temples, and monasteries.) (Throughout the learning process, students will not only get familiar with the major religious traditions in East Asia, but also increase awareness of the different perspectives in understanding the role of religions in ancient and modern society. They should also develop interpretative and critical skills in reading primary sources and secondary sources.)

requirement_sentence: (Same as WGS 385W 1) (Studies of queer Asian America span an immense diversity of histories and lived experiences and reflect the vast interdisciplinarity of their practitioners. They often combine political, artistic, and/or cultural work with more conventional modes of academic production. This course will engage a broad range of genres that shape, express, and analyze queer life in Asian America (including drag, poetry, ethnography, film, and theory). It will also consider how transnational lives involve processes of translation and layered identification that complicate queerness itself, questioning the adequacy of globalized terms for genders and sexualities.)

This field course will give the student a real hands-on rainforest experience, complete with bromeliads, toucans, sloths, and the sounds of the night. Graduating Seniors and students who have previously completed BIOL 371/ENVS 371 have priority for this course. Cost for the trip is approximately $3200 (depending on airfare prices). Permission of instructor is required. This course is taught by Dr. Lawrence Wilson (lwilso3@emory.edu; adjunct faculty), is SHARED by the Biology and Environmental Science Departments, and may be taken as elective and upper-level laboratory credit for the biology major. Biology majors may submit an application to Barbara Shannon at barbara.shannon@emory.edu (and Leah Thomas in ENVS at leah.thomas@emory.edu for ENVS 372). Selected students will be notified and will have additional requirements by OISP. See the OISP website for additional information. Financial Aid scholarships from the Biology Department are available to eligible Biology majors who submit an application for the aid.

requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 270 1, ANT 285 1, and LACS 270 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Tradition-Christianity, Region.) (Throughout history, crimes have tested and measured the social and cultural values that hold human beings together. In a society such as New Spain (Mexico) articulated around the defense and propagation of Catholic religion, religious crimes constituted a threatening subversion of the colonial discourse that justified the Spanish presence in Mexico, and a contradictory expression of the social tensions lived in the Spanish colony. This course will look at colonial society through the lens of crime by analyzing some of the main transgressions prosecuted by the Mexican Inquisition between 1520 and 1820, and the specific historical circumstances in which the trials took place. Our goal will be not only to analyze the reasons for inquisitorial repression, but also to disentangle the tensions lived in the social fabric of the colony in light of the classic divides of race, class, and gender.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course introduces students to statistical methods used in social research. It fulfills the sociology major requirement for a statistics course and a MQR general education requirement. Topics covered include descriptive and inferential statistics, levels of measurement, central tendency and variability, sampling distributions, interval estimation, and hypothesis testing for both categorical and continuous variables. By the end of the semester you should be able to (1) identify appropriate statistical methods for analyzing data, (2) critically assess basic statistical information from sources such as news articles and academic journals, and (3) use the program SPSS to conduct your own statistical research. Particulars: Take-home assignments and in-class quizzes Textbooks, Articles, and Resources

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 285 1) (This course examines the theory of Black capitalism within a wide range of American contexts, varied by place and time. First, students are exposed to a tradition of radical scholarship that analyzes the intersections - or articulations - between racism and capitalism. We will explore some seminal texts by WEB DuBois, Manning Marable, and Cedrick Robinson, among others. Then students will also gain an understanding of how local economic development works to support or obstruct Black capitalism. Particular attention will be paid to how growth versus redistribution strategies impact Black communities. It will end by considering the intersection of race and class in struggles for economic and social justice - from Black celebrities to voters, to activists and politicians.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: The course is about the structure, roles, and the collective and individual functions of schooling. This sociology course is also ideal for those students interested in public policy, education processes, and social inequalities. It surveys the social, political, economic, and cultural influences on schooling and educational outcomes in contemporary U.S. and, to a degree, global society. It will focus especially on schooling inequalities according to racial, ethnic, immigrant, class, gender, and sexual status, as measured by educational achievement and attainment, and which are often inherent to the structures and processes of U.S. schooling. The course also examines the interconnection of schooling to important social institutions, such as families, and their contribution to schooling inequality. The course will consider classic and current theories in the sociology of education, and address controversies within existing educational policy, including current reform efforts and recent neoliberal developments such as school choice.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: As an introduction to the field of Latinx Studies, this course explores the diversity of Latinx experiences and lifeways in the US through an interdisciplinary lens. The course will focus on the historical and political contexts that impact Latinx racialization, and class formation,. Beginning with an interrogation of the term Latinx and the history of Latinx Studies as a discipline, topics to be explored include, race, indigeneity, racism and colorism, colonialism and imperialism, Latinx feminisms, queer Latinidades, migration, diaspora, language, citizenship and social movements. The course will be attentive to regional differences (Latinidad in LA, NYC, Atlanta, or rural Arkansas) and differences in communities of origin (Latinidad as experienced by Hondureños, Puerto Ricans, Tejanos, Cubans, Mexicans, Dominicans, etc.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 329 1) This course is a survey of the Jewish experience in America, examining the religious, cultural, political, and economic activities of American Jews from the colonial period to the present. Students will explore the ways Jewish tradition has adapted to America, how patterns of communal life have been transformed, what the relationship of American Jews has been to other Americans and to the international Jewish community, and how American Jewish identities have been created from Jews' dual impulses for integration and distinctiveness. We will also use the Jewish experience as a means of evaluating different definitions of American national identity.

requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 338 1) (On the eve of the Holocaust, a majority of world Jewry lived in Eastern Europe, especially Poland and the USSR. This course explores the origins, dynamic growth, and near destruction of East European Jewry from the Middle Ages to the Holocaust and the challenges to Jewish life in this region in the post-WWII era. Many of the signature features of modern Jewish life - Hasidism, modern Jewish literature, Yiddish, Zionism, revolutionary socialism - derive from the centuries-long robust Jewish civilization in Eastern Europe.) (This course will make extensive use of primary documents - legal charters, memoirs, Hasidic tales, short stories, war reportage - to give us the tools to reconstruct this history together. We will also watch films and critically assess the recent Broadway versions of Fiddler on the Roof. As an add-on to this course, there is an optional 1-credit, twelve-day travel course to Poland, "Jews of Poland: History and Memory", which will be offered in May 2026.)

requirement_sentence: We are about to celebrate the 250th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence. This course, on the history of the American Revolutionary era, will consider it as a political, military, social, and economic event. We will study the most important American figures, including Washington, Jefferson, Franklin, Hamilton, and Madison, but also the most important British and French ones, including Lord North, King George III, General Cornwallis, Louis XVI, and the Count of Vergennes. The lives of ordinary American men and women, free and enslaved--will be compared with the lives of the powerful and we'll read a wide selection of works by soldiers, politicians, propagandists, mercenaries, and loyalists to explore the complexity of this dynamic historical period. There will be two papers, two midterms, and a final exam.
