requirement_sentence: (Same as PORT 385 2) Brazil is one of the world's largest, most diverse, and most unequal countries. Its history interweaves the experiences of Indigenous peoples, enslaved Africans, and immigrants from across the globe. This course explores Brazil's multiethnic society from the period before European arrival to the present. Students will analyze how different groups navigated and challenged political systems sustained by slavery, and how abolition, immigration, industrialization, and urbanization reshaped the nation. The course will consider Brazil both as a unique case study and within broader global patterns of colonization, development, and modernization. This course demands active student participation. Weekly readings and discussions will connect past and present, examining how historical patterns continue to shape contemporary Brazilian society. Students will approach historical questions using a range of methodologies and sources, including primary documents, visual materials, and oral histories, to construct evidence-based historical arguments. In addition to weekly writing, students will produce three papers, including one based on off-campus research. The reading load, which includes a textbook, articles, and primary documents, will often exceed 100 pages a week.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: What is the place of human beings in the modern world? In examining the social, political, technological, and aesthetic changes that characterize modernity, and various reactions to them, this discussion-driven course will survey many of the most important intellectual and cultural trends of the past 150 years. Beginning with the promise and threat of both science triumphant and Nietzsche's attacks on false certainties, it will move on to explore decadence, vitalism, the cult of violence, modernism, Communism and fascism, existentialism, feminism, the cultural effects of the two world wars, and the many and varied consequences of the turn to language and representation as the fundamental philosophical problem: structuralism, post-structuralism, deconstructionism, and postmodernity generally. Assessments include one short essay (4-5 pp.), two short analysis papers (2 pp. each), and EITHER a final research paper (9-10 pp.) OR a final exam, plus attendance and active participation.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as LING 446W 1 & QTM 446W 1) The course deals with new tools of analysis and visualization of text data. It is a 4-credits course, fulfilling the writing requirement with extensive weekly writing. The course does NOT require any prerequisites or prior knowledge of computational tools. Freshmen are not allowed to register. Text corpora will be assigned for analysis but students are welcome to use their own texts (e,g., newspaper articles, books, blogs). The course is based on a set of specialized Natural Language Processing tools (NLP), written in Python, designed for the analysis of small/large corpora of text. The tools come with an easy-to-use Graphical User Interface (GUI). From sentence splitter, to tokenizer, lemmatizer, parser with its Part-of-Speech tags (POSTAG), Dependency Relations (DEPREL), Named Entity Recognition (NER), semantic trees, sentence complexity and text readability, noun and verb analysis, n-grams viewer, sentiment analysis, topic modelling, extraction of SVOs (Subject-Verb-Object), and shape of stories, word embeddings (Word2Vec) you will learn the language of Natural Language Processing (NLP). The course also embeds tools of data visualization as word clouds, Excel-type charts, network graphs, and Geographic Information System (GIS) maps. The course uses freeware software exclusively. The course has no required books.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) ATTENTION!: Reading, Focusing, & Expanding Your Mind Everyone wants your attention: advertisers, social media influencers, politicians, college professors. But what will you pay attention to? Do you get to choose? Should you even try to control your attention? In this seminar we will explore how our views on attention relate to big questions in life: what to concentrate on, what to filter out, and how to open yourself to new ideas and experiences. We will be guided by transformative texts from a range of cultures, time periods, and disciplines that pull us into different kinds of attentive states toward our surroundings, literature and the arts, our inner lives, and the lives of others. Readings include works of literature, psychology, spirituality, and science by authors such as Sophocles, Virginia Woolf, Rabindranath Tagore, and Sigmund Freud. You will be part of a project designed by faculty from thirteen different departments that will change the way Emory students experience the life of the mind and find intellectual community. Sections of this course will join together for activities outside of class in which you will pay attention to campus and its surroundings, as well as to your classmates' perspectives.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 371 1 and WGS 385 2) What forms did the relationship between gender and law take between 1200 and 1800? In this class, students explore this and related questions, assessing Christian and Jewish women¿s access to the law, their agency within legal processes, and their marginalization. Students engage with historical sources and draw on gender and legal studies, alongside various fields of history, to examine these questions as a lens into power relations and broader legal, religious, and social developments during this diverse period. We will also probe societies and communities and their evolution over time, tracing continuity and change in women¿s legal standing, and reflecting on women and the law in modern and contemporary societies. Some of the questions we will ask include: What is the relationship between law and lived legal experiences? What strategies did women develop to navigate legal situations that affected themselves, their families, and their communities? How did they engage with marriage and divorce laws, as well as matters related to family law and inheritance? Were women involved in crime, and were there particular crimes associated with women? Did the law hinder women¿s roles in business? While this class primarily focuses on Europe, we will also examine the diverse legal standings and lived experiences of Muslim women, drawing comparisons between Europe and the Middle East, including the Ottoman Empire.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Any one SOC course as prerequisite or equivalent transfer credit. Seminar on sociological aspects of Apollo space era (1961-1972), focusing on social and cultural aspects of four new realities: "Spaceflight," "Astronaut," "Astronaut Family," and "NASA." Students use primary source material from the Stuart A. Rose Library and the Apollo 15 Learning Hub to create final projects. Class Notes Only 12 humans have walked on the Moon; only 24 have orbited the Moon. No human has been beyond Earth's orbit since the last Apollo lunar mission in 1972. The Apollo missions were extraordinary scientific achievements; they were also historical events located in particular social contexts. This seminar course takes a sociological approach to explore the Apollo era (1961-1972), focusing on four main areas: "Spaceflight" "Astronaut," "Astronaut Family," and "NASA." We will begin with brief background on the political, technological, and broader social contexts of the time. Then we will delve deeper into various social and cultural aspects of these four new realities: "Spaceflight" (e.g., media constructions and projections), "Astronaut" (e.g., links to test pilot culture; gendered construction of a new occupation), "Astronaut Family" (e.g., relationship with the press; the unpaid work roles of wives; creating new NASA communities) and "NASA" (e.g., PR efforts and image constructions; early organizational culture). Students will work with primary source material from the Stuart A. Rose Manuscript and Rare Book Library, the Emory Center for Digital Scholarship's Apollo 15 Learning Hub as well as other digital archival material (from data collected by Professor Scott) to create their own projects on one of the main topic areas. Requirements: Three short research assignments that will build into a final project, in the form of an op-ed article. Drafts of the final project will be peer reviewed and discussed in class. Class attendance and discussion are integral to this course. Prerequisite: one Sociology course.

requirement_sentence: (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) (Complete Topic - Perception: Experiencing the World) We will study what has been learned about our sensory systems and how they work. Each sense is unique and the systems that process each type of sensation is distinct. "Sensation and Perception, 5th Edition" (Oxford University Press) will serve as our text as we explore this fascinating field. As with any significant question of nature, it is important to go beyond the borders of any specific field of study to develop a complete understanding. In our course, we will focus on the neurobiology supporting subjective experience, but also consider concepts from cognitive science and philosophy of mind. This will be an interesting and exciting study of one of the most important natural science questions of our time.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course will introduce you to the broad field of Developmental Biology. The fertilized egg, a single cell, gives rise to many cells that form complex multicellular organisms with many different cell types, tissues, and organs. The overall goal of developmental biology is to elucidate the cellular and molecular processes that control this amazing achievement. The study of development spans molecular biology, cell biology, genetics, embryology, and importantly, evolution. These perspectives will be used to explore general principals and fundamental mechanisms that are shared between many diverse organisms, focusing on invertebrate and vertebrate animals. This includes consideration of human development with examples of medically relevant disorders and social and ethical questions related to the field. This course fulfills the Column A requirement (or elective credit) for the Biology major. Prerequisites: Biology 142 + 142L.

requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 385 2) (This class covers not simply the rule of Putin but the Russia he was born into, the nature of his Late Soviet society, his political career in the unstable period following the collapse of the Soviet Union and his reigns as prime minister and president. The class will cover topics as diverse as illiberal democracy, wars of conquest, the creation of a petrostate, the taming of the oligarchs, the alliance with religious conservatives, as well as such issues as cultural control and sexual politics. Students will write weekly short reflections, an end-of-term video reflection, a historiographic essay on a topic of their choosing and take a final oral exam. Putin has shocked the world with his invasion of Ukraine, find out not only what makes him tick but also how the Soviet Union shaped him and how he shaped Russia. We will be reading portions of Alexievich's Second-Hand Time, Short's Putin, Lacqueur's Putinism, and additional readings that will be provided to students.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 423W 1) (This course will concentrate on the broad experience of Muslims within various Russian states. Russia has been Europe's largest Muslim minority state since the 16th century and Muslims still make up about 14% of the Russian Federation's population, making them a major contributor to Russian history. Muslims were variously persecuted, wooed, assimilated, tolerated, forcibly converted, protected, "ignored," "modernized," socialized and granted independence and autonomy by various incarnations of the Russian state. Topics such as the conquest of Kazan and the steppe, the establishment of state-controlled Islam, the colonization of the North Caucasus and Central Asia, the shock of war and revolution, forced secularization, the late Soviet rise of a political Islam, and post-Soviet political Islam will all be discussed. Students will be required to make an oral presentation, write a book review of a class book and write a final research paper.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 170 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Region, Theme.)( (Complete Topic: Yoga: Practices of Mind and Body in Hinduism, Jainism and Buddhism) (This course will survey the terrain of mental and physical culture in the South Asian traditions of Hinduism, Buddhism and Jainism. We will read from primary sources, root texts and commentaries as well as modern scholarship on the vast diversity of practices that are united in their self-characterization as `yoga,' irrespective (as well as cognizant of) their religious and sectarian differences. We will study the chronological development of the concept and practices associated of yoga, its distinct uses and applications in the three religious traditions in play, as well as its transformation and applications in the modern global marketplace of self-culture.) (The course will foreground lenses of gender, race, caste and colonialism to evaluate how their interplay has determined the reception, definition and practice of yoga in modernity. The course will also attend to the inter-relations of mental and physical practices in these three religions with Sikh and Sufi traditions in South Asia. Lastly, it will emphasize both the theory and practice of yoga as intertwined and mutually shaping each other.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course satisfies the Religion major requirement: - Theme. Complete Topic: Religion and the Quest for Meaning. How should we live? What and whom should we care about? What are the commitments and projects that bring purpose to our lives? These are among the most enduring and important questions humans have wrestled with, questions demanded of anyone aspiring to live a meaningful life instead of sleepwalking through it. In this course, we explore the human quest for meaning through a survey of the world's religious traditions. Religions have always been among the most reliable sources of moral ideals, and among the most successful at inculcating those ideals through the practices, communities, and narratives they provision. Yet the centrality of religion for moral formation stands in tension with the secular and pluralistic character of the world we now inhabit. In this course, we attend to the difficulties as well as the possibilities of forging connections, communities, and commitments when traditional religious outlooks are no longer widely shared or taken for granted. We also query the limits of the category of "meaning" by considering aspects of religion that go beyond discursive coherence, that tap into the irreducibility of human experience.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Content: A continuation of Elementary Greek I (GRK 101 at Emory or the equivalent is a prerequisite). This course continues the introduction of the basic grammar and syntax of classical Greek within its larger cultural context. The course aims to move students into reading selections from major classical authors as quickly as possible. In the second semester, we will be reading adapted selections from Plato, Aristophanes, historians, and the orators, chosen to illuminate the history and culture of ancient Greece at its zenith. Texts: (students enrolled for the first semester will already have these texts). JACT, Reading Greek: Text & Vocabulary (Cambridge UP) ISBN: 978-0521698511 JACT, Reading Greek: Grammar & Exercises (Cambridge UP) ISBN: 978-0521698528 Particulars: Quizzes, three or four tests, and a final examination. Classwork and homework are important components of the final grade.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: How did ancient Greeks go to war, hold a festival, build a city, define their culture? This course explores the world of the people who spoke Greek, knew Zeus, and sailed from one end of the Mediterranean to the other. Our geographical range will reach from the coasts of modern Turkey to Greek cities in Sicily; our chronological span begins with the first appearance of human beings in the Greek islands, and ends with the world created by Alexander the Great. Our readings are primary sources, including archaeological sites, artwork, ceramics, architecture and human remains; theatrical performances, athletic competition, rhetorical and philosophical schools; literary selections from epic, lyric, drama and history, as well as the archaeologies of war and violence, cultural identity, colonization, and mobility. Grades are based on in-class exercises, midterms, and a final exam.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ANCMED 101 1 and JS 180 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Region.) (Topic: People and Their Gods) (This course provides a survey introduction to the study of the distinctive and interrelated cultures of the ancient Mediterranean world, from the Bronze Age until the Christianization of the Roman Empire (ca. 3300 BCE to ca. 400 CE). Under the subtitle, "People and Their Gods," the course gives special attention to cultural phenomena identified with the category of "religion." Drawing on a range of evidence, both material and literary, we will explore how ancient Mediterranean people understood and interpreted stories about gods and other powerful beings ("myths"); polytheism and monotheism; veneration of images ("idolatry"); tradition and innovation in religious beliefs and practices; the sexualities of gods and human beings; the significance of sacrifice (including human sacrifice); how Jews and Christians viewed so-called "pagans" and how "pagans" viewed Jews and Christians; the ancient Mediterranean roots and sources of present-day religious traditions.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ARTHIST 222 1) Roman civilization, from the Republican through the Imperial periods, transformed the art and architecture of the ancient Mediterranean. Innovations in engineering and technique, the introduction of new materials (like concrete), and the Roman genius for cultural assimilation all combined to create an art which was exciting as well as eclectic. Indeed, Roman art has often been characterized as the first truly modern art. The course will investigate the ways in which major achievements in sculpture, painting, numismatic and glyptic art, as well as architecture often reflected contemporary developments in Roman politics, society and religion. In addition the course will explore the relationship of works of art and architecture erected in the city of Rome to those in the provinces, the interaction of public and official art to domestic art, as well as the impact of art commissioned by imperial and elite patrons on that commissioned by non-elite patrons. Art History major/minor: Division I Architectural Studies minor: elective

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: The Aeneid and The Divine Comedy are both central texts in the western literary canon, closely linked by the literary genre of epic and even more by the profound influence of Vergil on Dante's conception of his poem. Yet they are strikingly different too: Virgil's epic of national origins places the cataclysmic events of his own lifetime in a scheme of fate and historical causation reaching back to Rome's mythic origins, while Dante's poem, though also deeply ingrained in history, explores the place of the Christian soul in the great drama of sin and redemption. Vergil and Dante both became national poets in retrospect, and both conceived their great works under the profound influence of previous epic poetry. For Vergil that previous influence was primarily Homer, for Dante Vergil. Our primary goal is a close reading of both poems in their contexts, but we shall also consider how literary canons are formed, how works are re-read in later times, and what the definition of a classic is. Both works will be read in English translation, but students with knowledge of Latin or Italian or both will be invited to contribute their perspectives based on reading in the originals as well.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as PHIL 190 3) (Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement: - Tradition-Buddhism.) (Suffering is a universal feature of human life. No one who lives does not also suffer. This insight is the starting point for the Buddha's teachings on the nature of the human condition and the possibility of human flourishing. Although suffering is universal, diverse causes of suffering can be identified. Once identified, these causes can be ameliorated so that the suffering they produce is either less harmful or even eliminated. Humans can learn how to live with suffering and to transform it into something beautiful, just as a gardener uses manure to nourish beautiful flowers. To turn suffering into a path of well-being, however, requires many skills. We need to learn how to look deeply to see the complex causes of suffering. Then we need to learn to see how these causes can be ameliorated or even undone. We also need to train in the methods for ameliorating and undoing the causes of suffering. These methods require work at the personal as well as the communal levels, at the surface as well as the deeper levels of our embodied minds. This course is an introduction to traditional and contemporary Buddhist theories of well-being, happiness, and flourishing, along with some of the methods designed to bring these about.)

requirement_sentence: (Same as ARTHIST 319R 1) "Egyptian Art in the Greek and Roman Periods: Crossroads of Cultures"This course examines ancient Egyptian art produced between approximately 332 BCE and the end of the fourth century CE, a period when Egypt was governed by Greek and Roman rulers. Although often overshadowed by the artistic achievements of earlier times, the visual culture of Greek and Roman Egypt offers vital insights into how art functions as a medium for expressing identity, negotiating power, and navigating cultural boundaries. Far from being a time of decline, these periods witnessed the construction of great temples, the creation of new works that fused indigenous Egyptian forms with the styles and mediums of Greek and Roman art, and the production more mummies than any other time in Egyptian history. Through close analysis of sculpture, architecture, painting, and funerary art, this course will explore the resilience and dynamism of Egyptian cultural identity in a cosmopolitan world.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 258 1, ANT 258 1) This is a fascinating time to be - or just learn about - Judaism and Jewishness. We are less than a century out from the genocidal devastation of the Holocaust, the birth of the State of Israel as the first independent Jewish commonwealth in almost two millennia, unprecedented freedom for Jews in many (but not all) parts of the world, and vast migrations by almost every historical Jewish community to a different part of the world than it lived in a century ago. Surely, these are features of the modern Jewish condition we will need to discuss anthropologically. We also live in an age of unprecedented technology and shifts in worldview. Can a genetic profile "prove" Jewishness? In what special ways are some women using assisted reproductive technology or "reproductive tourism" to fulfill Jewish kinship or social and religious expectations? Some of the most interesting anthropological research on Jewish communities today centers on these issues. This class takes place at a moment of increasing political polarization, including confrontations with legacies of (and contested definitions of) race, gender, and antisemitism. Do the new discussions of race and gender, as well as the politics of "diversity, equity and inclusion" make it harder or easier to identify and respond to key elements of the modern Jewish condition, individually or collectively? Has it grown easier or harder to answer the old question whether "Jewishness" is primarily a religious, ethnic, racial or national designation [spoiler: these are not the only options]? Does it matter? To whom? What is actually at stake in these conversations? Finally, we may be at something of a crossroads for the history of anthropology as a research discipline. Along with reading about the sheer diversity of ways of being, thinking, or living Jewishly, we will acknowledge the fraught Jewish history of the anthropological discipline, and ask some critical questions about its future. Is anthropology today capable, given the tools at its disposal, of rendering an adequate account of modern Jewish life? Why, for the most part, has it failed to do so (ok, that's another spoiler alert)? How has the modern Jewish condition impacted the anthropological project from its beginnings, and how might clearer thinking about Jews, Jewishness and Judaism contribute to new forms of anthropological thought? How can we read current ethnographies of Jews and Judaism critically to better understand what they tell us about the Jewish world, how they do it, and what they can learn to do better?

(Throughout history, crimes have tested and measured the social and cultural values that hold human beings together. In a society such as New Spain (Mexico) articulated around the defense and propagation of Catholic religion, religious crimes constituted a threatening subversion of the colonial discourse that justified the Spanish presence in Mexico, and a contradictory expression of the social tensions lived in the Spanish colony. This course will look at colonial society through the lens of crime by analyzing some of the main transgressions prosecuted by the Mexican Inquisition between 1520 and 1820, and the specific historical circumstances in which the trials took place. Our goal will be not only to analyze the reasons for inquisitorial repression, but also to disentangle the tensions lived in the social fabric of the colony in light of the classic divides of race, class, and gender.)

requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 268 1, HIST 268 1, POLS 268 1) The Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: Political Struggles, Personal Histories gives students an overview of Israeli-Palestinian conflict from the 1880s on through today. It introduces students to early Zionist debates and the late Ottoman context before moving on to discuss violence during the British Mandate period, the rise of the State of Israel, and the reappearance of the Palestinian cause on the world stage after the 1967 war. The course will include sessions that examine previous bouts of armed conflict as well as various attempts at peace, but war and politics will not be the course's only foci; the lived experiences of Palestinians and Israelis will also receive significant attention, from historical times through the present day. These voices include a young Jewish female spy who helped the British defeat the Ottoman Empire; an Islamist rebel whose death inspired the Great Arab Revolt of the 1930s; a Holocaust survivor who fought in the 1948 war before becoming Israel's leading poet; girls whose families fled from Jerusalem and Libya, and grew up amidst poverty and war; a U.S.-trained heart surgeon-turned-PLO militant who was assassinated in his quest for peace, and many others.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 270 1, HIST 270 1) This course is a survey of Jewish history from antiquity to the present. It presumes no prior knowledge of Jewish history, religion or culture. We will examine how Jews have defined themselves socially and politically in a number of historical and geographical settings, how Jewish theology and religious practice have been shaped and transformed, and how Jews have interacted with and responded to the societies in which they have lived. A central question during the ancient period will be, what was "Judaism" and how did it emerge out of the diverse religious landscape of antiquity? The medieval period will focus on the interface between Jewish communities and the states or empires in which they lived. Particular attention will be paid to the interactions between Jews, Christians, and Muslim peoples and cultures. In the modern period, we will analyze the processes by which governments, politicians and some segments of Jews attempted to incorporate the Jews and Judaism into European society and the various problems and reactions engendered by the quest for Jewish emancipation and social integration.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course, while open to all undergraduates, is a required course for undergraduate students at Emory majoring in Religion. The aim of the course is to introduce students to the study of religion as an academic field so that they may better situate their own research and writing within the larger landscape of modern scholarship in this area. Students will become familiar with major sociological, anthropological and hermeneutic approaches which pursue questions about the function, origin, comparison and language of religion. We will explore key terms in the contemporary study of religion such as culture, body, performance, rationality. Throughout, we will be concerned with the ways in which the category of religion has been and continues to be constructed by those who study it. This class is designed to increase students' methodological self-awareness as scholars of religion.

(In this exciting new course called Psychology of the Black Church Experience, we will explore the intersection of Black psychology and African American Christianity through the lens of the Black Church. From a critical psychological approach, we will examine how the Black Church functions as a social, spiritual, and psychological support system in historical and contemporary racial experiences for Black people in America. Aspects of the Black Church experience that this course will examine include its historical relevance in America, racial identity and empowerment, gender socialization, spiritual experiences, the Black family, and mental health and healing. We will delve into topics like communal identity, leadership dynamics, coping mechanisms, and the Black Church's role in social activism, community development, and mental health within Black communities.)

(This writing-intensive seminar takes a broadly philosophical approach to the study of Buddhist understandings of the nature of goodness and how goodness can be recognized and cultivated. Materials for the course will range from Buddhist scriptures, to philosophical treatises, to narratives, to poetry, and to films. The intention of the course is to engage seriously with Buddhist understandings of the nature of the human condition as infused with suffering, and how humans can nevertheless develop goodness and resilience within this fleeting and unstable world. Topics include the extent and limits of generosity, the proper objects of loving-kindness and compassion, the moral consequences of truths and falsehoods, and mind-training techniques for taking obstacles as the path.) (Writing assignments will be weekly and will emphasize engagement with the course materials. There will be a final written project that builds on the work done during the semester.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ANT 385 7, HLTH 385 13, and JS 370 1) (Complete Topic: Sacred Bioethics: Ethnography, Religion and Assisted Reproductive Technology.) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Theme.) (We live in a world of increasing biotechnology. Surrogacy, IVF and the potential for cloning are just a few of the technologies that have raised important questions about how human beings reproduce as well as the costs and responsibilities associated with any creation of new life. Who should be considered the mother of a child born through gestational surrogacy? Is reproductive cloning a potentially exciting new technology or a nightmarish assault on what it means to be human? What, if any, limits should be placed on "reproductive tourism" in which women from poor countries bear children for women from rich ones? These are not simple questions.) (We also live in a world of deep religious and cultural diversity, in which biotechnology is used, interpreted and developed with the needs, concerns or values of different communities in mind. Though often portrayed as value-neutral, the science of reproduction cannot help but raise questions of value that cannot, by their nature, be adjudicated by science or medicine alone.) This seminar explores the ways in which different religious and cultural traditions have grappled with the ethical implications of new reproductive technologies. Students are expected to gain comparative knowledge of two kinds: 1. Understanding some of the varying ways in which different religious traditions (such as Judaism, Christianity, Islam or Hinduism) have defined and evaluated bioethical dilemmas. 2. Understanding how different scholarly disciplines (such as anthropology, theology or comparative religion) can contribute to better understanding of bioethical dilemmas and the people who face them.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: ITAL 470 Italian Cinema. Neorealism to the present Prof. Achille Castaldo / Tuesdays and Thursdays 1:00-2:15PM Content: A history of Italian cinema from the mid-20th century to the present day (with some forays into contemporary Italian TV series). This class will explore both major and lesser-known movements, directors, and genres, with a particular focus on neorealist films and aesthetics in the light of their international resonance. We will focus on historical topics, including fascism, youth culture, terrorism, mafia, migration, and film aesthetics (such as the construction of pathos, landscape, memory, and charisma). Authors will include well-known personalities such as Roberto Rossellini, Michelangelo Antonioni, Pierpaolo Pasolini, Lina Wertmüller, Liliana Cavani, and contemporary filmmakers who are revitalizing Italian film aesthetics, like Alice Rohrwacher and Pietro Marcello. Class discussion will be in Italian, but subtitles in English will be available for all films.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This senior symposium for Religion majors asks: "What's the point of a Religion major in 2026?" It looks to pull together some threads of previous coursework in religious studies as a capstone, and it also serves as a steppingstone to look beyond graduation into how the study of religion might contribute to one's life. As a capstone to their academic work, students will develop a research paper on a topic of their choice. As a steppingstone, students will examine how religious studies might relate to future careers and engagements with diverse communities. Throughout the course, we will invite past Religion majors and people using religious studies in their careers into the classroom. We will also venture out to religious sites in and around Atlanta.

When we dream of different futures, what forms does gender take in those futures? Reading science fiction, African and Afro futurism, and speculative fiction, and viewing some television and film selections, our course explores the ways in which science fiction can reveal how we understand gender and society. Introducing concepts from feminist science studies, we will examine the intertwining of gender, sex, race, and technology.

requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, YOU MUST ATTEND THE FIRST CLASS session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. Nonfiction Magazine and Long-form Writing. No pre-requisite. This class is NOT open to first-year students. This workshop is focused on long-form, nonfiction magazine and feature writing -- reading it, reporting it, writing it, and doing so in ways and by means that separate the exceptional from the pedestrian. This is nonfiction. Be prepared to be a reporter, to meet people face-to-face, to ask questions, to see and hear things with your own eyes and ears. My goal is to get your work published. We'll have visiting experts on hand as we discuss where great ideas come from, how to be strategic in your reporting, the art of the interview, and crafting stories, then stories within stories. We're looking mostly at print, but we will see beyond the dead tree media at the growing opportunities for magazine-style writing and long-form narratives online. Ultimately, the goal of the course is for you to become a considerably wiser and more effective nonfiction storyteller, for which the basis is sound reporting. Students should budget to purchase the textbook and for photocopying.

requirement_sentence: WGS205W Introduction to Studies in Sexualities This course is an introduction to the interdisciplinary field of sexuality studies. It will explore the diversity of contemporary sexual experience, sexual behavior and sexual identity, and put into question what we take to be natural, normal or liberatory about these experiences, behaviors and identities. This exploration will be guided initially by the influential work of Michel Foucault. What is the relation between sexuality and repression? What is the relation between sexuality and power? We will be particularly interested in the status of homosexuality in contemporary theories of sexuality. Beginning with pre-Stonewall homophile politics in the US and moving through the radical era of the 1970s, the course will investigate the foundations of current queer theory and activism. In the last part of the course, we will explore four key contemporary debates in sexuality: adolescent sexuality; queer cinema; pornography; queer comics.

requirement_sentence: The science of gender slowly and unevenly moves from the lab to the clinic. Healthcare access, effective diagnosis, and treatment depend on clinicians, use of masculinity, femininity, and forms of non-binary gender identity. This class examines the experiences of patients as they navigate illness and health. By studying how healthcare providers and researchers seek to understand gender and deploy gender identity in delivering care, students explore the life-and-death stakes of cultural investments in gender and health. Readings and course material will juxtapose health systems across a range of historical periods and geographic settings so that students may compare and contrast gender normalization from one setting to the next.

requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 385 3, CPLT 389 2, and PHIL 385 2) (Women and the Law: historically, politically, and socio-culturally, these two terms have a long-standing relationship with one another. They shape one another inasmuch the latter has also historically enervated the former's rights and possibilities. Similarly, the two terms, "woman" and "law," are often contested terrains in regards to their respective meaning, interpreting the ways in which they have been constructed, and their roles in culture, society, and the unconscious. These moments are even more intensified in the ways they have been racialized and stand within a longer racial history of terror. To this extent, the course begins by examining the racial construction of gender and how the law becomes a tool of racial, ethnic, sexual, and gender repression. It will explore cases in slave law to broaden its view on constitutional and statute law as well as other concepts of laws (e.g. psychic, notions of sexual difference, aesthetic). Throughout, attention will be given to film and media representations of law, gender, and race to consider our course explorations. The course centers black feminist thought and critical race theory as its main analytic lens, and will examine how these two intellectual and political traditions remain critical in our contemporary landscape.)

(In this course we will examine the underlying causes of human behavior and traits, focusing particularly on the use of quantitative genetic methods (i.e, twin and adoption studies) to disentangle genetic and environmental influences. We also will review molecular genetic methods for finding specific genes that underlie behavior. We will begin by reviewing the historical backdrop to behavior genetics, including a focus on Charles Darwin, Francis Galton, and Gregor Mendel. We will proceed to examine the use of twin and adoption studies to disentangle genetic and environmental influences, and the advantages of these methods over family studies. We will then review various molecular genetic methods for finding specific genes. We will end by exploring the results of quantitative and molecular genetic studies of various forms of psychopathology, personality, and behavior. Textbook: Behavioral Genetics / Edition 7; Publication Date:10/02/2016; Publisher: Worth by Valerie S. Knopik, Jenae M. Neiderhiser, John C. DeFries, Robert Plomin, Charles Darwin. On the Origin of Species; either hard copy or pdf posted to Canvas.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: One hundred compelling works of art form the nucleus of "Encounters with Art & Architecture II," an innovative course addressing key issues in the history of art and architecture. Why is a picture worth a thousand words? What makes a building political? How does a statue represent cultural ideals? What is art, anyway? Encounters encourages us to look both at and beneath the surface to question appearances, challenge preconceptions, and seize the significance of the smallest detail when engaging with art and architecture. In Encounters with Art & Architecture, every member of the Art History faculty lectures in their area of expertise on several of their favorite things. By hearing so many voices, you'll gain an appreciation for the variety of approaches we take to understand human creativity in visual and spatial form. In weekly discussion sections, you'll talk about what you've learned and encounter works of art in person during visits to the Carlos Museum and the Rose Library. "Encounters Part II" introduces images, objects, and buildings produced from the seventeenth century to the present day, in Europe, Africa, and North America. Art History major/minor: core requirement

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Trans Cultures in the US: We often hear talk of "trans community," "trans culture," and "trans people" today; yet, before the late 1990s, there was no concept of a shared trans community, culture, or politics in the US. Instead, what we might retrospectively identify as trans cultures were dramatically divided along lines of sexuality, gender, class, and race. Pre-1990s trans cultures differed in their understandings of what it meant to be trans, interactions with trans medicine, and political interests. Today, a discourse of shared trans community, culture, and politics tends to obfuscate the persistence of divisions of race, class, gender, and sexuality between trans people and trans cultures. This course will introduce students to the pre-1990s cultures of working-class transfeminine street queens and drag queens, working-class Black and Latina ballroom femme queens, white, upper-middle class heterosexual cross-dressers, transsexual women desperately trying to stave off downward mobility, working-class butches, and passing men. We will analyze what happened during the 1990s to create a shared "trans community," and whose class and race interests won out in this process. We explore a wide genre of artifacts to get to know these trans cultures including oral histories, autobiographies, magazines, documentaries, ethnographies, sociological reports, and medical texts.

In the context of the manual « Imaginez, 5th edition », and its fully integrated accompanying literary and cultural texts, audio recordings and songs, videos and short films, students get an in-depth review of the basic patterns and structures of French. During this journey to different parts of the French-speaking world, students have the opportunity to reactivate their previous knowledge of the language and to expand upon that base so that they can communicate with confidence. Required Textbooks, Articles, and Resources: Champeny, Séverine, "IMAGINEZ: le français sans frontières, 5th Edition". Vista Higher Learning, 2020. ISBN: 978-1-54330-546-3. Students will need the supersite access code. May be purchased via the VHL website or Emory bookstore. requirement_sentence: (This course is part of Emory's Voluntary Core Curriculum program) Much of our life experience is shaped by buildings. The greatest of them stand as icons of their respective cultures, embodying religious, social, and political ideals; economic and technological realities; and aesthetic aspirations. In this course we explore some of the greatest buildings of world architecture from ancient Egypt to the twentieth century. With a single building, or group of buildings, as the focal point of each lecture, we will move through time considering issues such as: materials, massing, and monumentality; the Vitruvian triad of firmitas, utilitas et venustas (strength, utility, and delight); gravity-defying Gothic structures; domes and their reinvention; the aesthetics of technological innovation; the myriad directions of contemporary design. The subject is vast. Rather than trace a linear history we have selected major monuments that drive the development of architecture. These are the buildings you know by sight but will come to understand in depth. Architectural Studies minor: core requirement or elective Art History major/minor: makers & materials course

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Freshmen Only) Writing in the City From graffiti scrawled on highway overpasses, advertisements on buses, op-eds in local papers, to books on urban theory, the city is a locus of writing. In this course, students will learn key components of composition by exploring writing of and about city environments, with a focus on our city, Atlanta, in particular. Students will learn about Atlanta in the post-Reconstruction era up to the present as well as the history of select places within the city. By reading diverse modes of writing of and about urban environments, students will be invited to reflect upon their embodied relationship to writing, place, and the connection between the two. Major assignments include weekly short writing assignments, a personal narrative, an inquiry-based research paper, a multimodal remix, paper revisions, and reflections.

Content: This course will consider and analyze women's roles in resistance, collaboration, witness and testimony during major conflicts of the last century: WWII, the Sino-Japanese War, the Algerian War, the American-Vietnam War, the Rwandan Genocide. Working through historical fiction written and/or directed by women, students will study the ways in which gender, memory, trauma, and political agency are represented and redrawn in times of war. The cell is an amazing network of self-organizing machinery that drives life in all its forms. This course begins by defining the molecular wheels and cogs of the cell's machines and how their capabilities are defined by their chemistries. The chemistries of each component are then explored to understand how they contribute to the operation and control of the cellular machinery. We will further explore how all of the cellular components are governed, by kinetic and non-kinetic controls, to produce a coherent and responsive metabolism that efficiently creates and utilizes the energy stored in chemical compounds, such as glucose and fats. Human metabolic disorders such as diabetes will provide models of how metabolism is controlled at the systematic level in complex organisms using biochemical signaling pathways to coordinate metabolic pathways in different tissues. This course will fulfill elective credit for the Biology major and should provide students with a firm foundation in Biochemistry.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Topic: What Happens to the Self at the End of the World?) (In times of political upheaval, boundaries are both erected and eroded. Borders, identity categories, properties, alliances: these all enter a period of change or upheaval. These boundaries organise the social world, and their erosion signals periods of change, when things get weird. In this course, we will explore the weird as it impacts the political, social, psychological, and ecological, asking, "What happens to the Self at the End of the World?" We will move through psychoanalytic theory as well as affect theory to gain perspective on this question-others have asked it before and we will read while coming to our own answers, together. No prior knowledge of psychoanalysis or affect theory is needed. Readings and assignments will aim to be exploratory and generative. Ephemera such as zines, political pamphlets, and social media posts receive the same seriousness of attention as peer-reviewed articles and 17th century source texts. We will read excerpts from Freud's Civilisation and its Discontents, Spinoza's Ethics, and Raymond Williams's Marxism and Literature, alongside action reports from Stop Cop City activists, and blog posts from Ismatu Gwendolin, cultural worker and activist known for her teatime TikTok lectures.) (Show-and-tell, zine-making, and video projects will join with your written work; each student will bring their own respective style and medium to assignments in this course. We each have our own expert knowledge on the subject of what it means to be a Self. We will each bring this to the table as we discuss together, the Self, the World, and the End.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Topic: Gender-Based Violence in Anglophone and Francophone Caribbean Women's Literature) (Discussions of gender-based violence are rarely present in theoretical works by Black studies scholars and decolonial thinkers. This course aims to address this issue. We will open this course with Myriam Chancy's Framing Silence, which highlights how Haitian women writers are able to supplement the absence of women in traditional historical narratives through literary means. This phenomenon was not only seen among Haitian women writers, but among Anglophone and Francophone Caribbean women writers in general. Building from this work, this course will explore how Anglophone and Francophone Caribbean women writers such as Sylvia Wynter, Gisèle Pineau, Shani Mootoo, Nalo Hopkinson, Fabienne Kanor, and Edwidge Danticat include portrayals of gender-based violence in their works to theorize racism, sexism, and coloniality. We will also read theoretical works that address the relationship between gender-based violence and coloniality by Achille Mbembe, María Lugones, and Malcolm Ferdinand. Assignments for this course will include short response papers, a midterm paper, and a final essay.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Topic - Surrealism: Theatre, Painting, Poetry) (Following World War I, "surrealism" emerged alongside several avant-garde art movements in Europe. While hugely inspired by Dada, surrealism's revolutionary attitude came from combining avant-garde sensibilities with the insights of Freudian psychoanalysis. Artistic creation would be informed by theories of the unconscious and the strange world of meaning that we encounter in dreams. The ideas of surrealism were applied in literature, painting, photography, architecture, theatre, etc., and also went beyond art into a major critique of politics. In this course, we will read, analyze, and discuss works from the founding generation of surrealists and the intellectual circle surrounding André Breton. Our focus will be to examine and compare works from three components of the surrealist movement: theatre, poetry, and painting. We will begin with the formal and linguistic innovations of surrealist poetry, then move to depictions of the work of desire in painting, and conclude with the radically improvisational Theatre of Cruelty. Key writers and artists will include Paul Éluard, Georges Bataille, Antonin Artaud, Salvador Dalí, and Frida Kahlo. Some of the larger questions we will address are: - How are the theoretical ideas of surrealism affirmed and contested by different artistic media? - How do surrealists respond to the traditional values of "high art"? - How can we cultivate the "wild eye" when viewing visual art and hear the "surrealist voice" in poetry? - What do surrealists mean when they speak of new forms of life? - How does surrealism relate to revolutionary politics? Assignments will include reflections on writing produced using surrealist methods (automatic writing, the "cut-up method"), a set of "close readings" of paintings, and a research paper discussing class-relevant topics.)

(Topic: People and Their Gods) (This course provides a survey introduction to the study of the distinctive and interrelated cultures of the ancient Mediterranean world, from the Bronze Age until the Christianization of the Roman Empire (ca. 3300 BCE to ca. 400 CE). Under the subtitle, "People and Their Gods," the course gives special attention to cultural phenomena identified with the category of "religion." Drawing on a range of evidence, both material and literary, we will explore how ancient Mediterranean people understood and interpreted stories about gods and other powerful beings ("myths"); polytheism and monotheism; veneration of images ("idolatry"); tradition and innovation in religious beliefs and practices; the sexualities of gods and human beings; the significance of sacrifice (including human sacrifice); how Jews and Christians viewed so-called "pagans" and how "pagans" viewed Jews and Christians; the ancient Mediterranean roots and sources of present-day religious traditions.)

requirement_sentence: (Same as WGS 358 1, AAS 385 3, and PHIL 385 2) (Women and the Law: historically, politically, and socio-culturally, these two terms have a long-standing relationship with one another. They shape one another inasmuch the latter has also historically enervated the former's rights and possibilities. Similarly, the two terms, "woman" and "law," are often contested terrains in regards to their respective meaning, interpreting the ways in which they have been constructed, and their roles in culture, society, and the unconscious. These moments are even more intensified in the ways they have been racialized and stand within a longer racial history of terror. To this extent, the course begins by examining the racial construction of gender and how the law becomes a tool of racial, ethnic, sexual, and gender repression. It will explore cases in slave law to broaden its view on constitutional and statute law as well as other concepts of laws (e.g. psychic, notions of sexual difference, aesthetic). Throughout, attention will be given to film and media representations of law, gender, and race to consider our course explorations. The course centers black feminist thought and critical race theory as its main analytic lens, and will examine how these two intellectual and political traditions remain critical in our contemporary landscape.)

First, students are exposed to a tradition of radical scholarship that analyzes the intersections - or articulations - between racism and capitalism. We will explore some seminal texts by WEB DuBois, Manning Marable, and Cedrick Robinson, among others. Then students will also gain an understanding of how local economic development works to support or obstruct Black capitalism. Particular attention will be paid to how growth versus redistribution strategies impact Black communities. It will end by considering the intersection of race and class in struggles for economic and social justice - from Black celebrities to voters, to activists and politicians.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ANT 258 1, REL 258 1) This is a fascinating time to be - or just learn about - Judaism and Jewishness. We are less than a century out from the genocidal devastation of the Holocaust, the birth of the State of Israel as the first independent Jewish commonwealth in almost two millennia, unprecedented freedom for Jews in many (but not all) parts of the world, and vast migrations by almost every historical Jewish community to a different part of the world than it lived in a century ago. Surely, these are features of the modern Jewish condition we will need to discuss anthropologically. We also live in an age of unprecedented technology and shifts in worldview. Can a genetic profile "prove" Jewishness? In what special ways are some women using assisted reproductive technology or "reproductive tourism" to fulfill Jewish kinship or social and religious expectations? Some of the most interesting anthropological research on Jewish communities today centers on these issues. This class takes place at a moment of increasing political polarization, including confrontations with legacies of (and contested definitions of) race, gender, and antisemitism. Do the new discussions of race and gender, as well as the politics of "diversity, equity and inclusion" make it harder or easier to identify and respond to key elements of the modern Jewish condition, individually or collectively? Has it grown easier or harder to answer the old question whether "Jewishness" is primarily a religious, ethnic, racial or national designation [spoiler: these are not the only options]? Does it matter? To whom? What is actually at stake in these conversations? Finally, we may be at something of a crossroads for the history of anthropology as a research discipline. Along with reading about the sheer diversity of ways of being, thinking, or living Jewishly, we will acknowledge the fraught Jewish history of the anthropological discipline, and ask some critical questions about its future. Is anthropology today capable, given the tools at its disposal, of rendering an adequate account of modern Jewish life? Why, for the most part, has it failed to do so (ok, that's another spoiler alert)? How has the modern Jewish condition impacted the anthropological project from its beginnings, and how might clearer thinking about Jews, Jewishness and Judaism contribute to new forms of anthropological thought? How can we read current ethnographies of Jews and Judaism critically to better understand what they tell us about the Jewish world, how they do it, and what they can learn to do better?

(Same as NBB 301L 1) (Topic: Neural Data Simulation & Analysis Lab). Students who were on the BIOL 360L/NBB 301 wait list in Fall 2025 AND Spring 2026 graduating senior Biology majors who need to fulfill their upper-level lab requirement have priority for this class. Contact Barbara Shannon at barbara.shannon@emory.edu for permission. Through this course, you will learn basic computational and programming skills and apply them to the simulation and analysis of neural data. Course instructors will provide introductory lessons on basic coding in Python, which will be used throughout the course through collaborative, group-based lab tutorials. The focus of this course will be to use these in-lab tutorials to understand how neuroscience data is structured, analyzed, simulated, and interpreted. The course will be divided into 2 portions: (1) coding, running, and interpreting simulations of neural activity, and (2) understanding the analysis of neural data. The course consists of lectures, group lab tutorials, and individual homework assignments for each module. This course originates in the Biology Department, and it will count as an elective and upper-level laboratory credit for the Biology major. (This course does NOT COUNT as elective credit for the NBB major; the catalog description is incorrect.) Prerequisites: Biology 142/142L and Chemistry 202; pre- or co-requisite: Biology 360/NBB 301).

We will build a critique of cultural production emphasizing an intersectional framework and critique of oppression via black studies, black feminisms, and sound studies. This class will bring together various media, social science, film, and art as we discuss legacies of blues, jazz, funk, hip hop, and techno. title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 270 1, MESAS 275 1) This course is a survey of Jewish history from antiquity to the present. It presumes no prior knowledge of Jewish history, religion or culture. We will examine how Jews have defined themselves socially and politically in a number of historical and geographical settings, how Jewish theology and religious practice have been shaped and transformed, and how Jews have interacted with and responded to the societies in which they have lived. A central question during the ancient period will be, what was "Judaism" and how did it emerge out of the diverse religious landscape of antiquity? The medieval period will focus on the interface between Jewish communities and the states or empires in which they lived. Particular attention will be paid to the interactions between Jews, Christians, and Muslim peoples and cultures. In the modern period, we will analyze the processes by which governments, politicians and some segments of Jews attempted to incorporate the Jews and Judaism into European society and the various problems and reactions engendered by the quest for Jewish emancipation and social integration.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 296 4) This course will explore the global history of antisemitism from antiquity to the present. Antisemitism is a modern term, but it has been used to describe a centuries-old fear that Jews somehow pose a threat to an existing social order. It constitutes the oldest continuous global tradition of prejudice towards any single group defined as the "Other." We will examine anti-Jewish prejudice in the realm of ideas and behaviors, attuned to changes in quality and intensity over time, and Jewish responses to violence and discrimination. We will explore the current rise of antisemitism, legal and definitional attempts to combat it, and the relationship of antisemitism to other forms of racism and anti-Zionism.

From a critical psychological approach, we will examine how the Black Church functions as a social, spiritual, and psychological support system in historical and contemporary racial experiences for Black people in America. Aspects of the Black Church experience that this course will examine include its historical relevance in America, racial identity and empowerment, gender socialization, spiritual experiences, the Black family, and mental health and healing. We will delve into topics like communal identity, leadership dynamics, coping mechanisms, and the Black Church's role in social activism, community development, and mental health within Black communities.)

requirement_sentence: This is an English Language Learner (ELL) course. Contact Jane O'Connor (jcoconn@emory.edu) for permission to enroll. Language, Land, & Place This course offers an introduction to various nonfiction genres (including flash nonfiction, photo-essay, and personal essay) and approaches to writing that destabilize standard academic English (including Indigenous language reclamation, multilingualism, and translingualism). We will read and discuss a range of scholarship in Black, Indigenous, Asian/American, and Latinx/Latine rhetoric, writing, and literacy; ground ourselves in our shared contexts of Atlanta and the larger Southeast; and develop shared practices of land- and place-based writing.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: We live in an era where data is one of the most valuable currencies. It shapes how companies see us, what they predict we'll buy, and even what keeps us scrolling. Big Data is at the core of many digital experiences, especially through recommendation systems, whether it's Netflix suggesting your next binge, Amazon curating your shopping list, or TikTok tailoring your For You page. But while these algorithms make life convenient, they also raise major ethical concerns around privacy, bias, and digital autonomy. This course will explore both the technical foundations of algorithms and their broader social implications. We'll break down how these systems work while also looking at how business incentives shape what gets recommended. While technical expertise isn't required, students who want to dive deeper into the computational or mathematical aspects can do so through projects and assignments.

title: COURSE ATLAS

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: FREN 310 or FREN_OX 310 and FREN 314 or FREN_OX 314 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. FREN 351: Media and Genres: Autofiction / Vivre l'autofiction (Prof. Giguere / Mondays/Wednesdays 11:30am-12:45pm). Content: While personal narratives that blend fact and fiction existed well before the term autofiction was coined in 1977, in this course we will consider the reasons why this genre has become ubiquitous in French and Francophone cultural and literary spheres of the 20th and 21st centuries. We will focus on the genre's flexibility and capacity to 1) communicate individual experiences as they relate to powerful, painful, and liberating social, political, and historical events and 2) communicate the complexity of these experiences not just through writing but across different media including graphic novels, photography, film, music, interviews, and social media. Primary Works; Perec, W ou le souvenir denfance Ernaux, Lévénement Faye, Petit pays Varda, Les plages dAgnès Supplementary texts may include excerpts/ short works by Barthes, Duras, Doubrovsky, Calle, Guibert, Satrapi, Darrieussecq (among others). Course Expectations and Assignments: - Active participation - Readings and collaborative [student and instructor generated] study guides for most sessions - One presentation - 2 short papers with drafts (4-5 pages) - 3 in-class responses (1-2 pages) - Final collaborative, multi-media class project

The development of a meaningful understanding of intermolecular forces and how these determine the physical properties of a material is a major theme of these studies.

requirement_sentence: This course provides a critical survey of the major movements, paradigms, and documents of European and American art after World War II. Special attention will be given to crucial problems like the relation of art to politics; art's response to mass media and technologies, consumer culture, and globalization; and the redefinition of artistic means. More broadly, we will study fundamental tools for examining works of art formally, historically, and critically. The course is not intended as a comprehensive survey of art after 1945; rather, it will address the complex set of aesthetic, philosophical, and political motivations that shaped the artistic production of select figures and movements, including Abstract Expressionism, Pop Art, Minimalism, Institution Critique, and Performance Art. Art History major/minor: Division III

You will develop and practice your English language skills by reading, listening to, and interpreting diverse texts, engaging in discussions and performing various other activities both inside and outside of the classroom. In addition, it will introduce you to life in America and American culture, history, and traditions through expert guest speakers. Each of you will also be paired with a writing center tutor and conversation partner for extra practice outside of the classroom.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: CHEM 202 or CHEM_OX 202 or CHEM 202Z or CHEM 221 or CHEM_OX 221 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. This course is NOT intended for students who took Chem 202Z in fall 2024; those students should take Chem 203Z.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: We live in a culture that is saturated by visual images. It is vital to understand what forces shape visual culture and how it shapes our thinking about a myriad of topics such as politics, race, religion, class, and gender. In this class we will explore the ways visual culture is produced, circulated, and consumed. We will examine visual culture in multiple mediums including art, architecture, photography, comics, digital media, advertising, and television. We will begin by studying the major theories behind visual culture. We will consider how issues of authority, power, and positionality shape the creation and interpretation of visual images. Students will become adept at "reading" visual images in the same way they read other texts, and the discussion-based course will give students ample opportunity to hone this skill.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: FREN 310 or FREN_OX 310 and FREN 314 or FREN_OX 314 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. (Same as AFS 389 5) FREN 391R: Interdisciplinary Arts as Healing Practice (Prof. Montlouis-Gabriel / Tuesdays/Thursdays 10:00-11:15AM). Content: As Fabienne Kanor reflects in an interview: "J'ai mal à mon histoire et la réécrire est le seul moyen que j'ai trouvé pour guérir un peu" ("My history hurts me, and rewriting it is the only way I have found to heal a little"). This course takes up Kanor's insight as its guiding principle, exploring how artistic creation becomes a pathway to healing from historical trauma. How do artists transform pain into power? How can creativity help us heal from historical trauma and imagine new possibilities? This course invites you to explore how predominantly Black women artists and artists featuring Black women characters across the francophone world (from Senegal to Martinique, France to Vietnam, Cameroon to Reunion Island) use film, literature, poetry, performance, and visual arts as tools for healing and resistance. Through hands-on creative projects and rigorous literary and cultural analysis, you'll develop your own practice while learning concepts like "cartographies of memory" and "aquatic metaphors" as ways to understand healing journeys across the diasporas. You'll collaborate with visiting artist TIE on her project "Odyssey in Black Utero," exploring how art creates healing pathways between past and future. Your final project? Create your own "map to elsewhere" a creative work that visualizes connections between historical memory and imagined futures. No prior art experience necessary: just curiosity and openness to creative exploration. Texts may include: Fabienne Kanor, Humus (excerpts) Léonora Miano, La saison de lOmbre Nadia Chonville, Mon coeur bat vite Maryse Condé, Moi, Tituba sorcière de Salem (excerpts) Alice Diop, Saint-Omer (film) Mati Diop, Atlantics (film) Alain Gomis, Félicité (film) Jean-Pierre Bekolo, Les Saignantes (film) Eva Doumbia, Autophagies (Theater) TIE, Odyssey in Black Utero (collaborative project)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as AFS 270W 1) We will think carefully about art, data, and their intersections. We will reflect on what data are, and we will also examine how data about art are often captured, parsed, and presented in museums, on maps, and in other places and formats. We will consider how space and place shape data as well as how data shape human experiences of space and place. In addition, we will think about how artists and other makers center data in their creative processes. Our studies of art and data will draw on specific examples linked to Africa and other geographies at different moments in time. Yet, the relevance of our investigations transcends any single geography or time period. And as a course in the humanities, we will also reflect on what it means for any person, whether from here and now or another place and time, to be human; to embrace our shared humanity; and to engage with digital technologies. The course is designed for curious students eager to reflect on what art and data can teach us about past and present human experiences and the world. The course features creative assignments. It also relies on students' deep reading, close looking, attentive listening, engaged discussion, and mutual respect; it is not a lecture course. Attention to wellbeing constitutes another aspect of the course design. No prior knowledge of Africa, art, art history, data, or design is necessary; all you need is a drive to learn and commitment to completing coursework.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: We will explore some key genres and styles of social science writing for the public. Through a series of small, multimodal writing and communication assignments, we will focus on matters of style: citation, perspective, verbs, conciseness and clarity, translation of academic research into lay language, etc. Short assignments will vary, e.g., informal, in-class freewriting; formal email; interviews and interview notes, etc. Students will not be conducting firsthand research but will be researching secondary literature, interviewing experts and perhaps community members or stakeholders, & translating these voices into finished assignments suitable for lay audiences. The course will have two major assignments on the same topic of scientific research: a live presentation and a written or recorded version of a project. Students will be encouraged to choose a topic of scientific research that relates to a community of which they are a part, and a topic, moreover, that has not been communicated clearly to the publics who have a stake in this scientific knowledge. Students will write with a particular audience in mind and though not a requirement possible venues for publication, and may be encouraged to pursue this goal beyond the end of the course. The class will conclude with students' self-reflection on their writing, in terms of three course outcomes: critical thinking, writing for a particular audience & purpose, & development of writing process.

title: COURSE ATLAS
