title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Through an interdisciplinary exploration combining social sciences, sciences, and humanities disciplines and methodologies, we will engage in creative and intellectually rigorous conversation about the human experience, while writing our own stories in the process. This course will progress through separate topical units centered around three core questions: -How do we understand ourselves? Why is it difficult to define what is human? Why do we need to think of humanity as a problem? -Human compared to what? Here we seek to further illustrate what makes humanity distinct through a comparative lens. What is a human compared to an animal, a robot, or even, considering our strange relationship to the nation-state, a citizen? In doing this, we will think deeply about how humanity defines itself through and against its own narratives of power and dominance. -Where are we going? In addressing this question, we will attempt to work through some of the largest existential threats to humankind and determine two things: How do different disciplines tackle these issues? And can these disciplines work together to solve them?

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: FREN 310, FREN 314 and two 300 level FREN courses, or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite. FREN 488. Hauntings: Literature, Psychoanalysis, Film Prof. Claire Nouvet / Mondays and Wednesdays, 1:00-2:15PM. Content: With the study of hysteria, Freud discovered the process of repression and elaborated the concept of the unconscious. The unconscious, however, does not rest quietly. It returns to haunt the present through various disruptions that conscious thought does not know how to explain to itself: slips of the tongue, dreams, phobias, anxieties, delusions. If we learn from psychoanalysis that a past that has been repressed can return to disrupt the present, literature, for its part, has its own way of staging these uncanny returns. What comes back under the figures of the ghosts, vampires, and witches that haunt the literary stage? How do traumatic histories haunt the next generations? And what happens to those who incarnate past histories that the present prefers to forget? These are some of the questions that we will address at the juncture of literature, psychoanalysis and film. Special attention will be given to the way psychoanalysis addresses the issue of trauma not only at the individual level but also at the collective level: transgenerational transmission of historical traumas. Texts may include: Freud: Introductory Lectures [selections] Studies in Hysteria [selections] Delusion and Dream in Wilhelm Jensen's Gradiva Balzac: Adieu Jules Barbey d'Aurevilly: Diaboliques Duras: Hiroshima, mon amour [film] Gauthier: Arria Marcella Michelet: La Sorcière Davoine and Gaudillard: History Beyond Trauma [selections]

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 385 2) (What is black existence? Can we imagine black existence without reason, the transparent subject, formalized schemes of knowledge, and being? How has anti-blackness (de)structured our relationship to time, space, and thinking? Is it time to abandon the human as an organizing concept for liberation and freedom? Using black psychoanalysis, black feminist poethics, ecological studies, Afro-pessimism, semiotics, black humanism, and black theology, we will address these concerns. Ultimately, we will sketch the infrastructure of black thought and evaluate the efficacy of various methodologies and noetic practices. This course will celebrate (and critically evaluate) the beauty of black thinking, its innovation, and development. The reading is primarily philosophical and theoretical (with artistic and cinematic engagements).

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as EAS 292 1) (This course introduces the arts of East Asia through focused case studies. We will explore tombs in which creative imaginations of afterlives were materialized, paintings and calligraphies that embodied kinesthetic energy, religious monuments that witnessed dynamic cross-cultural exchanges, and modern and contemporary artworks that captured the lived experiences of different communities in East Asia. The objects and sites under consideration both highlight cultural communications and address the distinctive identities of each tradition. Students will also explore East Asian artworks from local museum collections.) (Art History major/minor: Division II or IV)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Writing Amid Mis/DisInformation Doom scrolling might feel passive, but it demands constantly sorting through arguments of dubious credibility. Data-driven algorithms serve us information based on assumptions about associations that shape our points of view. Comments draw trolls who parrot talking points, equivocate, and gleefully misidentify fallacies increasingly, they're not even real people. Where are we to turn, as readers and writers, when faced with such erosions of trust and community? This course considers the usefulness of confronting mis/disinformation with rhetoric, which beyond persuasion, studies how language affects action. We will apply frameworks for evaluating arguments and information critically yet generously, while identifying rhetorical tactics and analyzing the role of sources, facts, and expertise. Readings and discussions will introduce representational ethics and reflect on when debate is worthwhile, given good/bad faith, alongside alternatives to agonism like listening and mutual vulnerability. Students will practice narrative and analytical writing assignments attentive to differences of perspective, evidentiary logics, and multiple affected communities.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Ecological Visions in Speculative Fiction (Same as FILM 286 1) This interdisciplinary course explores the intersections of ecology and speculative fiction across film, literature, and television. Students will examine how speculative narratives imagine the future of the planet, human-nature relationships, ecological justice, and the consequences of environmental degradation. With a particular focus on science fiction, the course also draws from climate fiction (cli-fi), Afrofuturism, and eco-horror, the course invites students to analyze how speculative storytelling critiques dominant environmental ideologies and proposes alternative ecological futures. We will investigate the narrative strategies used to render environmental crisis visible and consider the cultural and philosophical implications of these imagined worlds.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as CL 329 1) "Egyptian Art in the Greek and Roman Periods: Crossroads of Cultures"This course examines ancient Egyptian art produced between approximately 332 BCE and the end of the fourth century CE, a period when Egypt was governed by Greek and Roman rulers. Although often overshadowed by the artistic achievements of earlier times, the visual culture of Greek and Roman Egypt offers vital insights into how art functions as a medium for expressing identity, negotiating power, and navigating cultural boundaries. Far from being a time of decline, these periods witnessed the construction of great temples, the creation of new works that fused indigenous Egyptian forms with the styles and mediums of Greek and Roman art, and the production more mummies than any other time in Egyptian history. Through close analysis of sculpture, architecture, painting, and funerary art, this course will explore the resilience and dynamism of Egyptian cultural identity in a cosmopolitan world.

title: COURSE ATLAS

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as DATASCI 302W 1) (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Juniors and seniors with declared majors or minors offered by the Department of Data and Decision Sciences or the Writing (RWID) Program will receive permission codes for this course prior to the pre-registration period. DATASCI and RWID students must use the provided code to enroll during their assigned registration period. Enrollment will be on a first-come, first-served basis, and once the enrollment cap is reached, the waitlist will be activated automatically. For enrollment in ENGRD 302W 1 only: Non-RWID students may contact ahackne@emory.edu for a permission code after November 15, 2025. Technical Writing for Data Science prepares students to analyze complex information and produce clear, ethical, and reader-centered documents across professional contexts. Through hands-on projects and collaborative practice, students will learn to analyze writing contexts, manage the communication life cycle, and adapt style and format to diverse audiences and global contexts. Assignments across multiple genres such as an archival observation report, an interview transcript, and a formal cover letter will help students develop their written, oral, electronic, and visual communication strategies.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 354RW 1) (Topic: Buddhist Ethics) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement: - Tradition-Buddhism, Theme.) (This writing-intensive seminar takes a broadly philosophical approach to the study of Buddhist understandings of the nature of goodness and how goodness can be recognized and cultivated. Materials for the course will range from Buddhist scriptures, to philosophical treatises, to narratives, to poetry, and to films. The intention of the course is to engage seriously with Buddhist understandings of the nature of the human condition as infused with suffering, and how humans can nevertheless develop goodness and resilience within this fleeting and unstable world. Topics include the extent and limits of generosity, the proper objects of loving-kindness and compassion, the moral consequences of truths and falsehoods, and mind-training techniques for taking obstacles as the path.) (Writing assignments will be weekly and will emphasize engagement with the course materials. There will be a final written project that builds on the work done during the semester.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Troublemakers: Framing Outsiders in Modern European History - (Same as ARTHIST 385W 1) This course is designed to give students an understanding of modern European history, in approaching it through its people and forms of architectures. As we follow individuals, their trajectories, and constructions that sought to frame and control them, students with interest in the nineteenth century and from wide-ranging fields--history, art history, architecture, comparative literature, gender and sexuality--will interact with the materials in an interdisciplinary manner. Reflecting on history from the margins matters. It crystallizes practices of exclusion and sheds light on the workings of power structures. These are processes that are central to modern European history and continue to mark societies today.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as CL 329 2) "Elements of Greek Architecture" "Elements of Greek Architecture"More than two thousand years ago, ancient Greeks constructed temples that reveal a sophisticated command of planning, engineering, optical design, and mathematics. How did they achieve that? But also, are such temples their only architectural achievements worth studying? This course offers a broad introduction to Greek architecture, from monumental sanctuaries and civic structures to domestic houses and everyday spaces. The course covers the essentials: architectural orders and styles, building materials, construction techniques, and the roles of architects and workshops. At the same time, it addresses broader questions, such as: How did architecture shape ritual and social life? How did thresholds, lighting, and access structure bodily encounters with the sacred? How did houses and civic buildings reflect cultural values and community identity? In collaboration with Emory's Center for Digital Scholarship, students gain experience with digital tools used to reconstruct and visualize ancient buildings not only to see how they once looked, but also to explore how design affected movement, perception, and interaction, both with the divine and among mortals. Greek architecture, approached through architectural history, classics, anthropology, and digital humanities, emerges not only as a technical achievement but also as a cultural system that structured ancient lives, shaping notions of space, community, and the sacred. Art History major/minor: Division I Architectural Studies Minor: elective

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Ling 190: Slang! In this course, we will examine and analyze SLANG as a specific subset of language. Using theories and methods from structural linguistics, sociolinguistics, corpus linguistics, and the history of English, students will not only be immersed in previous research but will create their own projects and collect and analyze their own data. Students who decide to take this course agree to have civil, objective, and (mostly) mature discussions about a range of topics. Please note that, due to the nature of this course's topic, a lot of the language that we will be discussing is considered taboo by some. If you are easily offended by so-called coarse language or topics such as sex, bodily functions, or body parts, this may not be the course for you.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: "Chinese Buddhist Art and Monument"Brought to ancient China by travelling merchants and monks, Buddhism was once a foreign religion. Yet not long after the initial introduction, Buddhist art and monuments flourished and gradually became a part of Chinese visual culture. At times, Buddhist art helped to build a cosmopolitan society that encouraged foreign trade. In other times, painting Buddhist subjects and visiting ancient Buddhist sites were high-minded pursuits of educated Chinese elites. Women from different social classes also found motivations to participate in the making and collecting of Buddhist art and materials. This course explores grandiose sculptures, mural paintings, cliff-carved cave-shrines, paintings, prints, and textiles in Chinese Buddhist visual culture. We will address how issues of politics, patronage, gender, and economy shaped the production and reception of Chinese Buddhist art. Art History major/minor: Division II or IV

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Race, Gender, and Media-Making: "The US Black Press at (Almost) 200!"In 1827, Freedom's Journal became the first newspaper owned, edited, and published by Black Americans in the United States. In spring of 2026, we will anticipate an important 200th anniversary for Black print culture by exploring the history and development of newspapers, magazines, and other print genres created by and for Black people across North America. We'll read literary magazines, abolitionist newspapers, fiction from periodicals, and more! across almost a century of print culture. Assignments include Hoax/SciFi article, "News in the News" presentation, and a long-term Wikimedia project contributing metadata and original Wikipedia articles about the US Black press.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Attention Ecology: Social Media and Our Responses In this upper-level writing course, we will turn our attention both towards and away from the social media industry. By attending to the history and present of what Neil Postman named "media ecology" as well as the emergent discourse concerning the "attention economy," this class seeks to understand how various forms of social media shape how we think, speak, act, and exist in the world. From this study arises a particular question: can we do anything about it? Seeking to proffer alternatives how might we spend our time otherwise? what might we do instead? This class will also engage meaningfully with various rhetorically rich practices of making meaning and meaningfully making. "With ten thousand rituals," writes Jim Harrison, "I paint time and mortality, not only to make them endurable but to give them the dimension, splendor, resonance, perhaps beauty, that I sense they deserve." What will our (new) rituals be?

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ANT 203 1) What do you know when you know a language? How did you come to learn this information so quickly? How do the world's languages differ? How do linguists study language? This course explores the complex nature of human language and introduces students to the scientific study of human language. As we unpack our knowledge of language, we will explore speech sounds (phonetics), sound systems of language (phonology), word and sentence formation (morphology and syntax), how language expresses meaning (semantics), and how context influences the interpretation of meaning (pragmatics). We will also study language in a broader human context, investigating the role of language in defining human society. Additional topics include historical linguistics, language typology, sociolinguistics, and language acquisition.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Literature & Environment: Nature Writing Labs: This seminar invites students to explore the environmental humanities and nature writing through a range of inquiry, observation, and research. Guided by activity labs from dissecting owl pellets to growing pollinators, students will engage in writing and revision as processes of wonder and discovery. Selected texts on ecological topics will span time, genres, modalities, and disciplines, and will guide students in composing their own critical and creative projects.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Before you enroll: Be advised that this class is NOT an introductory Linguistics course. It will be assumed that students are already familiar with the goals of linguistic inquiry and the methods of basic syntactic analysis (trees, categories, constituency tests). If you have not taken Foundations of Linguistics (LING-201/ANT-203), or an equivalent course, you will be required to do significant extra self-instructional work at the beginning of the semester. What we do in this course: Much of the language you hear over the course of a day consists of sentences you have never heard before, and yet you are able to understand them. How is this possible? The principle of compositionality states that the meaning of a sentence is determined by the meanings of its words and the way they are combined. In the first part of this course, students will learn a system for doing just this - combining phrase structure trees and computing the meanings that result, using the formal language of predicate logic to represent sentence meanings. Then, in the second part of the course, we'll focus on utterance meaning - aspects of meaning that go beyond what is shown in the predicate logic. For example, what enables us to understand a sentence like `There's ice cream on your shirt' as a simple informative description in some contexts, as an accusation in others, and as a warning in still others? We'll discuss speech acts, implicature, presupposition and other aspects of utterance meaning as we explore the close relationship between semantics and pragmatics. All required readings will be made available online.

In this 1-credit seminar, you will return to and revise the web-based portfolio that you started building earlier in the program. Your goal will be to synthesize the work you've done as a writer and learner at Emory - within the minor, and beyond - by curating and showcasing what you consider your best work. As you grapple with how to portray a version of yourself and the commitments you've developed from your experiences, we will take a metadisciplinary and rhetorical approach to this representation. We will reflect on how you have learned to create meaning in your fields and communities, in terms of what you have been taught to value and come to value personally in your scholarship. Moreover, you will practice using writing and speech to show this approach to others who may or may not have the same backgrounds as you do. The course will culminate in an oral "defense" of your portfolio, where you will present what you've created to me, your peers, and others in the Writing Program.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as CL 487W 1) "Picturing Others: Race, Ethnicity, and Representation between the Near East and Greece" What makes someone a foreigner? And what role do images play in shaping how societies portray, classify, and engage with those deemed alien, foreign, or other? Across the ancient Mediterranean, peoples of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and Greece with their different languages, religions, skin colors, and traditions shared spaces, traded, exchanged ideas, and forged alliances, but also fought, invaded, and enslaved one another. How did these interactions, both peaceful and violent, influence the ways they depicted one another as foreigners, neighbors, defeated enemies, and racialized others? And how did such ideologically and culturally charged representations, in turn, shape lived encounters between different populations? This course draws on visual, material, and literary evidence from Mesopotamia, Egypt, and Greece (ca. 18004 00 BCE) to examine the role of ethnic and racial representation in constructing power dynamics and shaping human relations in the ancient world. Through lectures, discussions, readings, and direct engagement with the Greek, Mesopotamian, and Egyptian collections at the Carlos Museum, students will critically analyze how visual and textual sources depicted foreignness, difference, and otherness, and how these depictions structured broader patterns of cultural interaction, political authority, and social hierarchy. Art History major/minor: Division I

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course is designed to help IDS and American studies majors in the Institute for the Liberal Arts (ILA) to develop their senior thesis. During the course of the semester students will learn how to design a strong and compelling academic research project. Students will gather, read, and analyze academic sources related to their intellectual interests and use them to identify a research topic, develop a research question, think about relevant theories, and choose a research method to help answer their question. Students will design a well-organized plan of research, culminating in the submission of their thesis prospectus and the completion of a presentation at the ILA Spring Research Symposium. During the semester students will complete a variety of assignments to familiarize themselves with the research resources available on campus. They will also work on developing their research network, by meeting to discuss their ideas with faculty in the ILA and across campus. As a cohort, students will work together to build a strong community of researchers who support one another through the highs, plateaus, and lows of research.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Research on the earth's fragile mountain regions has focused on the effects of climate change, biodiversity, and sustainable development. While such work is imminently important, this course looks at how humans have related to and interacted with mountains in literature and film. Beginning with climbing documentaries such as Free Solo, we discuss the increasing popularity of rock and gym climbing to investigate how previous mountaineers and inhabitants of mountain regions have depicted their forays. We conclude by looking at future challenges and opportunities of mountain sports. Through narratives and film, group projects and personal explorations of local places and communities, this course pursues the question of what are the promises of outdoor recreation and what are its pitfalls.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as SPAN 303 1) In this course (taught in Spanish), we will explore how diverse pronunciations are produced and organized by Spanish-speakers (including native/heritage and second-language speakers). As part of this, we will compare typical pronunciations of Spanish with those of English, and we will examine how different communities assign different social meanings and values to different pronunciations (for instance, why and in what circumstances do people value positively or negatively pronunciations such as "ello están contento" as opposed to "ellos están contentos"). This semester, we will include a component focusing on how different pronunciations and intonation can contribute to the performance of literary, theatrical and other spoken-language texts/events. TEXT: Tuten, D. N., Tejedo-Herrero, L. F., R. Rao, & H. R. Clarke. 2022. Pronunciaciones del español (Routledge). PARTICULARS: This course is designed for a wide variety of students, including those for whom Spanish is a primary/native or heritage language as well as for those who are learning Spanish as a second language. This is an introductory course in Hispanic Linguistics and therefore no background in Linguistics is required. Span/Ling 303 is a core course for the Spanish and Linguistics Joint Major and a Foundational Course for the Spanish Major and Minor. It counts as an elective or HAL course for other Linguistics majors and minors. EVALUATION is based on attendance/participation, homework assignments, exams, and performance projects. PREREQUISITE: SPAN 212 or an Official Spanish Placement into our Foundational Course level (Span 300-318). Take the online Spanish Placement Exam at http://spanport.emory.edu/home/undergraduate/placement/index.html. For more information on Foundational Courses, please go to www.spanport.emory.edu.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: "Medieval Bestiary"Gargoyles, griffins, manticores, babewyns, dragons, snails, and even domestic cats inhabit all kinds of medieval art, jostling for attention with its religious subjects. The twelfth-century cleric Saint Bernard, whose detailed descriptions nonetheless betray a great attraction to the artistic creations, decried the "comely deformity and deformed comeliness" of the hybrid creatures carved in his cloister. Yet medieval writers also found profound moral and mystical implications in the lore of the natural world. This course will explore animal imagery in all media throughout the Middle Ages, but will focus on the bestiaries, the medieval illuminated books dedicated to animals. It is a literature greatly enhanced by scholarship associated with the Animal Turn, which seeks to recognize the massive interdependence of the human and animal realms. Major themes of the course include the importance of the ancient legacy and how it was adapted and transformed by medieval theologians and artists; the rising rates of literacy for which medieval bestiaries may have been instrumental; and the importance of contextualized study Art History major/minor: Division II

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 347 1, ANT 347 1) African American Language (AAL) is by far the most researched, the most publicly recognized, and most controversial language variety in the United States. AAL has long been a central object of study in North American sociolinguistics, where researchers have investigated its structure, its origins, and its current trajectories of change relative to Mainstream American English, and have simultaneously sought to combat misunderstandings about AAL (and all language differences) held by the public and the press. This course will be broken into four major sections: 1) Present-Day Features of AAL, with a focus on its vocabulary (lexicon), pronunciation features (phonetics and phonology) and grammar (morphology and syntax); 2) The History of AAL and its ongoing trajectory of change, focusing on earlier examples of AAL, its possible origins and whether or not AAL is diverging from Mainstream American English (MAE) and other varieties of English; 3) AAL as a Living Art will discuss AAL as it is employed as an expression of art by writers, musicians, as well as its use in African American speech events, and avenues for outreach; 4) AAL, Education and Society will examine issues related to AAL and education, the justice system, linguistic profiling and discrimination in other areas of society such as housing and employment.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as ENG 300W 1) Pre-1700 One semester of intensive language study will result in a proficient reading knowledge of the West Saxon dialect (standard Old English) such that we can explore the culture of the Anglo-Saxons and better understand the language we speak today. Selections from heroic and religious poetry and prose will begin with the first known poem in the English language and will also include the Wanderer and Seafarer, the Battle of Maldon, the Dream of the Rood, Ælfric's preface to Genesis, and King Alfred's lament over the faded glory of English learning. Classes consist of prepared translation, short lectures, and discussion. The standard lexicographic and bibliographic tools in Old English will be covered. Some previous foreign language study is desirable but not required; students should be prepared to use a glossary. We will also read Beowulf in translation, as well as selected passages in Old English.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: When we think about "the law," we tend to think about legal doctrine: written and somewhat rigid sets of procedures through which legal judgments are made. But when we approach the law historically, we see it as a process that changed over time under pressure from a range of forces: political, economic, social, and cultural; national, regional, and global; and driven by elites and people on the ground. The course is structured into three distinct units. Unit 1 addresses foundational inquiries pertaining to legal history. The objective of this unit is to establish a conceptual framework for analyzing law and legal orders in global perspective. Unit 2 investigates the interactions of law, society, and economy in a particular place and time, with emphasis on specific themes. Students will work with secondary literature, case studies, and primary sources. The content of Unit 2 varies, according to the research specialization and interests of the faculty member teaching the course. Unit 3 requires students to apply what they learned in Units 1 and 2 in a hands-on group project. In this iteration of HIST 210, taught by Professor Chris Suh, Unit 2 will focus on the topics of citizenship, civil rights, and precarity in the United States from the late 19th century to the present. Case studies will focus on Asian Americans' experiences with the law.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 329 1) This course is a survey of the Jewish experience in America, examining the religious, cultural, political, and economic activities of American Jews from the colonial period to the present. Students will explore the ways Jewish tradition has adapted to America, how patterns of communal life have been transformed, what the relationship of American Jews has been to other Americans and to the international Jewish community, and how American Jewish identities have been created from Jews' dual impulses for integration and distinctiveness. We will also use the Jewish experience as a means of evaluating different definitions of American national identity.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as AFS 221 1) (The media has often depicted Africa as a continent in turmoil, underlining military coups, war, famine, and disease. Yet those portrayals overlook the historical complexities that have led to current events. In this course, we aim to challenge limited narratives of Africa's contemporary realities by delving into the people, events, and processes that have shaped the continent. Given the vast size of Africa, the course will focus on specific themes and cases. These will include the end of the Atlantic slave trade and the transition to "legitimate" commerce; the motivations for and establishment of colonial rule; economic, social, and cultural transformations; African resistance to colonialism and decolonization; and post-colonial political trajectories. Altogether, this course examines the internal and external dynamics of change in Africa.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 338 1) (On the eve of the Holocaust, a majority of world Jewry lived in Eastern Europe, especially Poland and the USSR. This course explores the origins, dynamic growth, and near destruction of East European Jewry from the Middle Ages to the Holocaust and the challenges to Jewish life in this region in the post-WWII era. Many of the signature features of modern Jewish life - Hasidism, modern Jewish literature, Yiddish, Zionism, revolutionary socialism - derive from the centuries-long robust Jewish civilization in Eastern Europe.) (This course will make extensive use of primary documents - legal charters, memoirs, Hasidic tales, short stories, war reportage - to give us the tools to reconstruct this history together. We will also watch films and critically assess the recent Broadway versions of Fiddler on the Roof. As an add-on to this course, there is an optional 1-credit, twelve-day travel course to Poland, "Jews of Poland: History and Memory", which will be offered in May 2026.)

This course will follow the nation's transformation from a farmers' republic to an industrial giant, demonstrating the interplay between its democratic institutions, its dynamic capitalist economy, and its diverse population. Themes include immigration, transport, political reform, changing ideas about gender and sexuality, the two world wars, the "rights" revolution of the 1950s and 1960s, the Cold War, and the United States' emergence as the sole post-Cold War superpower. Classes will be a mixture of lecture and discussion of assigned readings, with an emphasis on student participation. There will be two papers, a midterm, and a final exam.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Same as ENG 389 1 Complete Title: Black Renaissances This course examines 2 of the most significant African American cultural movements of the 20th century - the New Negro Renaissance (aka the Harlem Renaissance, c. 1912-1932) and the Black Arts Movement (c. 1965-1979). While placing a primary emphasis on literary arts and authors, we will approach both movements as complex interdisciplinary, multi-generic phenomena concerned with Black freedom struggles. As we "map" the histories of these two major movements, we will consider the ways artists and critics alike have constructed these movements, the relationships of these movements to each other and to Black Studies, and the processes and politics that shape notions of literary history, race, gender, sexuality, and culture in American society.

requirement_sentence: (Same as REL 358R 1, ANT 385 7, and HLTH 385 13) (Complete Topic: Sacred Bioethics: Ethnography, Religion and Assisted Reproductive Technology.) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Theme.) (We live in a world of increasing biotechnology. Surrogacy, IVF and the potential for cloning are just a few of the technologies that have raised important questions about how human beings reproduce as well as the costs and responsibilities associated with any creation of new life. Who should be considered the mother of a child born through gestational surrogacy? Is reproductive cloning a potentially exciting new technology or a nightmarish assault on what it means to be human? What, if any, limits should be placed on "reproductive tourism" in which women from poor countries bear children for women from rich ones? These are not simple questions.) (We also live in a world of deep religious and cultural diversity, in which biotechnology is used, interpreted and developed with the needs, concerns or values of different communities in mind. Though often portrayed as value-neutral, the science of reproduction cannot help but raise questions of value that cannot, by their nature, be adjudicated by science or medicine alone.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 280W 1) (This course analyses German society under Nazism, especially Nazi efforts to establish the utopia of a racially, socially, and physically homogenous society. The creation of this "people's community" was to be achieved by violently excluding people who were deemed "deviant" from the norms the Nazi Party was propagating. The class examines the interplay between inclusion and exclusion and hence the production of "outsiders". Topics in this class include the biologization of politics; the application and radicalization of "racial hygiene" (eugenics); the history of the autism diagnosis; the regime's ableism; the persecution of homosexuals; and the centrality of antisemitism to all social and political Nazi projects. These topics will be introduced by an overview of the political history and ideology of German culture from the 1920s to 1945. We will analyze written primary sources, film propaganda, and present-day reverberations of this history. This course fulfills the Emory College Continuing Communication and Writing Requirement.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: Complete topic: Tropical Encounters: World Travel & European Identities, 1750 to the Present. Innocent sexuality, savage violence, pure humanity? What did European travelers seek "and find" among the peoples of the South Pacific, South America, and Africa? Through lecture and discussion, original sources and works by historians, this course examines both the encounters with other peoples and cultures in parts of the world previously little known to Europeans, and the uses to which the resultant travel accounts were put in disputes surrounding notions of race, the nature of humankind, and the practice of politics back in Europe. It traces the connections between journeys of scientific exploration, European imperialism, and the emerging disciplines of ethnography and anthropology from the eighteenth century through the twentieth. In this Continuing Writing course, you will build up to analyzing a travel account yourself in a final research paper (10-12 pp.) and presentation; a short essay, two short reading analyses, and active participation round out the graded assessments.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course requires BIOL 360 or NBB 301 or IBS 514 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite. The goal of this course is to provide students with a broad outline of ideas and current research areas in computational neuroscience, ranging from ion channels up to organismal behavior. Class meetings will consist of a combination of lectures and in-class computational exercises. Prerequisites: Biology 142 + 142L. Although the class will be largely self-contained, a working knowledge of introductory calculus, statistics, linear algebra, and some exposure to differential equations will be helpful (although a mathematical review will be provided). Knowing some neuroscience may also be helpful, but it is not required. Although most of the course will be taught in Matlab, only a working knowledge of basic programming control structures (e.g., for/while loops & if/then structures, etc.) is necessary, as we will devote time to coding tutorials at the beginning of the semester. If you have some coding experience but have learned R or C or Java or python, you should be fine. (This course is also taught as IBS 534.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as HIST 496W 1) How did an ethnic and religious minority in Europe experience the tumultuous years between 1492 and 1800, known as the early modern period? In this research seminar, students will take a deep dive into the history of European Jews, their relationships and interactions with majority societies, and the profound cultural, geopolitical, legal, religious, and scientific transformations that shaped this remarkable era in European and global history. We will therefore also use Jewish history to illuminate the histories of majority Christian societies. Students will explore themes such as expulsions, mass conversions, persecution, the print and scientific revolutions, the development of Jewish legal systems and Jewish engagement with non-Jewish law, conceptions of self and communal identity, messianism, the Reformations and the Thirty Years' War, mercantilism, and Jewish encounters with the Americas. The course compares Ashkenazi and Sephardi histories while rethinking the complex questions of minority belonging and exclusion. Students will strengthen their ability to analyze a variety of historical sources, including those produced by Jews as well as Christian sources that discuss Jewish life and culture. Students will apply their skills to write a 15-20-page research paper.

requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 268 1, POLS 268 1, MESAS 268 1) The Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: Political Struggles, Personal Histories gives students an overview of Israeli-Palestinian conflict from the 1880s on through today. It introduces students to early Zionist debates and the late Ottoman context before moving on to discuss violence during the British Mandate period, the rise of the State of Israel, and the reappearance of the Palestinian cause on the world stage after the 1967 war. The course will include sessions that examine previous bouts of armed conflict as well as various attempts at peace, but war and politics will not be the course's only foci; the lived experiences of Palestinians and Israelis will also receive significant attention, from historical times through the present day. These voices include a young Jewish female spy who helped the British defeat the Ottoman Empire; an Islamist rebel whose death inspired the Great Arab Revolt of the 1930s; a Holocaust survivor who fought in the 1948 war before becoming Israel's leading poet; girls whose families fled from Jerusalem and Libya, and grew up amidst poverty and war; a U.S.-trained heart surgeon-turned-PLO militant who was assassinated in his quest for peace, and many others.

This course will provide students with an overview of the sociological approach. Major theoretical concepts and methodologies will be examined and illustrated with a wide variety of classic as well as recent empirical studies. Some of the topics we'll look at include: social structure and culture in everyday life; societal views of death; socialization to gender roles; causes and consequences of major systems of social inequality (gender; race and ethnicity; social class). Requirements: Weekly readings, two papers, and two exams.)

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as JS 270 1, MESAS 275 1) This course is a survey of Jewish history from antiquity to the present. It presumes no prior knowledge of Jewish history, religion or culture. We will examine how Jews have defined themselves socially and politically in a number of historical and geographical settings, how Jewish theology and religious practice have been shaped and transformed, and how Jews have interacted with and responded to the societies in which they have lived. A central question during the ancient period will be, what was "Judaism" and how did it emerge out of the diverse religious landscape of antiquity? The medieval period will focus on the interface between Jewish communities and the states or empires in which they lived. Particular attention will be paid to the interactions between Jews, Christians, and Muslim peoples and cultures. In the modern period, we will analyze the processes by which governments, politicians and some segments of Jews attempted to incorporate the Jews and Judaism into European society and the various problems and reactions engendered by the quest for Jewish emancipation and social integration.

requirement_sentence: (BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or BIOL_OX 142 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite. (FULL TITLE: Models for Generating Hypotheses in Population and Evolutionary Biology.) This 2-credit hour course will introduce Juniors, Seniors, and interested graduate students to mathematical and computer simulation modeling in biology. The focus will be on the role of models used in developing hypotheses and of designing the tests of these hypotheses with experiments. Empasis would be on using models in population biology, ecology, and evolutionary biology, with particular consideration of bacteria, bacteriophage, and antibiotic treatment, as well as the practical (medical and epidemiological) application of the concepts of population and evolutionary biology. Models about the age and distribution of cancer will also be looked at. Students in this course will learn how to prepare a manuscript and will submit the manuscript to a journal, as co-authors. The class will learn how to use the Berkely Madonna software for the numerical solution to differential equations and Monte Carlo simulations. Prerequisites: Biology 142 + 142L and at least one course in Calculus, preferably Calculus for Biologists. Permission of instructor is required: Please contact Dr. Bruce Levin at blevin@emory.edu for permission.

requirement_sentence: Prerequisite: CS 253 Department permission required, please email bnflood@emory.edu. This class focuses on identifying and building interactive systems. This will include how to specify, design, and build user interfaces and systems that enable interactivity. Work will be justified in terms of how technical design choices enable or inhibit the user experience. The course will cover a variety of tools and techniques for creating interactive prototypes and user interfaces, examine their advantages and trade-offs for investigating and enabling user experience, and the related theory and principles for their implementation.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 247 1) For years we have understood that race is, biologically speaking, an exceedingly complex matter. Preconceived biases, much more than biology, govern the way people think about race. This course considers both the biological myth and social reality of race. We will focus on the social significance of race by examining the reality of racial stratification, the reality of the experience of racism, race, ethnicity, and nation, and the rationality of those who study racial dynamics and processes. The first portion of the course disentangles how race was leveraged to establish the sciences as an effective tool to understand and change society. The second portion of the course describes sociological theories of prejudice, privilege, and power to understand racism and racial stratification. The third portion of the course surveys empirical readings in Sociology that consider the state of ethnoracial inequality in the primary social institutions of society and everyday life opportunities. Throughout we consider how social change in social attitudes, classification systems, and policies shape the current global landscape of racism along the imperial projects of race, ethnicity, nation. The end product of the course increases competency in understanding the origins, dynamics, and state of racial and ethnic relations using the language and tools of Sociology through its scientific study of society.

title: COURSE ATLAS
requirement_sentence: This course addresses major themes and questions in the sociological study of criminology. We will examine some of the most influential explanations for criminal behavior, including strain theory and social control theory among others. The course will focus on the ways in which social context shapes beliefs about crime. What are the causes of crime? How can crime be reduced? In what ways is criminal justice decision-making influenced by race, class, and gender biases? To develop a thorough understanding of the nature of crime, we will examine a range of empirical work and substantive issues but will focus on issues around mass incarceration, prison systems, and white collar crime.
